SummaryOfEvents:
On 1st February 2008 the vessel (a dry general cargo vessel carrying a cargo of road salt) was on passage from Belfast to Inverness.  Soon after leaving Belfast the main engine temperatures started to steadily increase.   The oil pressure dropped and it was noticed that there was an increase in the engine oil level.

Tests of the oil confirmed that it had become water contaminated.  The problem was located on a cylinder head and water was seen to transfer to the head valve operating gear into the sump.  The Chief Engineer advised the captain to come immediately to anchor, but the harbour authorities objected because of the frequent fast ferry service.  The vessel was taken further out from the harbour, but the engineer became increasingly concerned about the oil contamination and firmly advised the master to anchor or else risk the engine being written off.  By now the vessel was about 3.5 cables from a pipeline - the captain decided that it was safe to anchor.  After doing so the engineers removed the affected cylinder head and found blanking and locating screws loose.  The cylinder head had been subjected to the manufacturer's overhaul and had only been fitted 2 weeks previously.

While the repairs were being undertaken SOSREP was informed and decided that in light of the weather conditions and the potential risk to the pipeline,  the vessel should be towed into Belfast.  The vessel arrived alongside about 7 hours later.  Repairs were completed by the crew while alongside, and the oil change completed.

Location: North Atlantic en route to Dover
SummaryOfEvents: On February 1st 2008 at approximately 12.30 hours LT the Liberian Flag vessel HORNCLIFF was at sea experiencing very heavy weather, which caused the vessel to pitch and roll. 70 containers were lost overboard and the Master and two passengers were injured. It was decided to evacuate them by helicopter, but due to the weather conditions and the ship's position this idea was aborted. On 2nd February, whilst approaching Lands End in Cornwall, the injured were eventually evacuated by helicopter and taken to hospital. After treatment, all made good recoveries, and the vessel proceeded to Falmouth to carry out heavy weather repairs.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents: At 23:35, Jan. 31st 2008, MV CMA CGM EVEREST collided with MV JIAO ZHOUHAI in waters nearby 31°48＇.7N/122°52＇.2E. The accident caused MV CMA CGM EVEREST suffered damage of No.4 cargo hold on the starboard side, and M/V JIAO ZHOUHAI suffered the break of the bulbous bow and depressed on the port bow. The two vessels all remain fit to proceed.

On the evening of 31st Jan 2008 the RoRo Freight vessel Riverdance was on passage from Warrenpoint to Heysham. The weather throughout the day had been strong Westerly gale force winds, increasing in strength. At the time of the initial incident winds force 10 were experienced along with large sea / swells.
Although the passage had been easy, with sea and swell coming from astern, as Riverdance approached the Lune Deep buoy she began to roll. Initially two trailers were reported to have shifted before the rolling died down. As the trailer shift was being investigated the rolling started again, stronger than before and resulting in cargo shifting from the trailers. A list of 45 deg to port was experienced and the master decided to bring the vessel head to wind. He applied full starboard wheel and the vessel turned rapidly, thus increasing the angle of heel. As the vessel became broadside to the wind this also added to the total heeling effect and a maximum list/heel of 60 deg was reported.
The vessel turned from a heading of 090 to 170 in 70 seconds. She then lost one of her two engines due to lube oil low pressure trip and would not come any closer to the wind. At this time the master contacted the Coast Guard.
Attempts to restart the engine were made and to transfer ballast to bring her upright. During this time Riverdance drifted towards the Shell Flat sands off the coast near Blackpool. Around 2300 hrs UTC she grounded on Shell Flat on a falling tide.
Initially 14 persons were evacuated by helicopter leaving 9 onboard attempting to stabilise the situation. Whilst aground the list decresed to about 25 deg. Ballast was transfered ready for coming off on the next rising tide in the morning. 
Once the vessel was starting to refloat the engines were put astern in an attempt to bring her into deeper water, the wind and seas were still storm force from the West and the engines had no effect. After about two hours, attempts to re float the vessel were stopped, Riverdance then came broadside to the weather and sufferred a sudden severe heeling over to starboard. The remaining crew were taken off the vessel and Riverdance was left aground with a heel of about 40 deg.
Subsequent attempts to refloat and salvage the vessel failed.

On 31st January 2008  the M/V SCHLESWIG-HOLSTEIN departed Fredericia Harbour. At approximately 16.45 hours LT  the ship collided with Skanseodde Lighthouse 0.7 nm east of the harbour.  The weather was bad. The wind came from south-west with a speed of 22 m/s, and the current was to the north-east speed 3 knots. Due to narrow waters and a considerable drift, it was difficult to manoeuvre the ship, and it collided with the lighthouse.

Location: The Downs - Off Deal in Kent
SummaryOfEvents:

During the morning the vessel made three circuits of the area, but on the last circuit she went further North than planned, and on making the turn to go South struck a charted wreck at approximately 12.50 hours LT.

Vessel sailed from Rotterdam to Jossingfjord. Orders came suddenly, no proper voyage preparation could be made, detailed chart of Jossingfjord was not on board. At arrival 30-01-08, 23.00 LT) vessel anchored outside the fjord (waterdepth > 37m), since according to the pilot, no achorage position was available inside the fjord. Both seacharts and sailing directions give warnings of "dangerous waves" in the area, but this was not noticed by the crew.
in the morning of 31st of January windforce increases towards 10BFt. At 11.00 hrs anchor is noticed to be dragging. Main engine is started, anchor heeved up. Due to wind and waves vessel is moving towards shallows rocks, near Baer-buoy. Vessel touches bottom several times with severe damage to hull and steering gear. After half an hour steering gear failure occurs. By means of bow thruster and ME, master succeeds to bring vessel to deeper water. Vessel towed to repair port.

Location: Babitonga Bay, in São Francisco do Sul
SummaryOfEvents: On 30 January 2008 the combined vessels pusher tug “Norsul Vitoria” and barge “Norsul 12”, flagged Brazil, Call sign PPTH, laden with 340 tonnes steel coils, capsized in the entrance channel of Babitonga Bay, at the entrance of the port of São Francisco do Sul. The convoy formed by the barge ‘NORSUL 12” and the pusher tug “NORSUL VITÓRIA”, is the type “Articulated Connection ITB” (Integrated Tug-Barge). The crew was picked up from the sea. The capsizing of the vessels did not cause any deaths amongst their crewmembers and their other occupants. All the upper works of the vessels were damaged, as well as the equipment on board. Right after the accident it was possible to notice presence of oil in the water around the vessels and, that after 12 hours, the oil stain had an extension of approximately 1500 m length by 300 m width.

The intention was to pick up the river pilot for the inward transit from the sea to the port of Wilmington, North Carolina USA. Several attempts to board the river pilot had failed due to the rough weather and wind conditions (winds blew at approximately 23 -24 knots). The vessel, while grounded in a low tide, suffered damage to the doubtle bottom tank areas, but without any breach or flooding of any kind, and no injuries were sustained. By 10.00 hours LT the next day the tide had changed and the vesssel refloated without any external assistance, and was fit to proceed with her journey. Flag State investigation was conducted by obtaining the Flag State report and follow-up communications for clarification after review, as necessary.

On 23rd January 2008 a fire broke out in one of the containers stowed on board the M/V WESTFALIA EXPRESS.  The Chief Officer raised the alarm at 19.50 hours LT, the crew were mustered, the deck lights switched on, the electrical supplies to the reefers were isolated and the fire pumps were started. The ship's speed was also reduced to dead slow ahead and her course was adjusted to reduce the wind over the deck. Four crew members fought the fire with sea water from hoses. Boundary cooling was also established. About 15 minutes after the fire was discovered, one of the containers exploded. Its door opened and its cargo of a white powder substance started to spill onto a hatch cover. Twenty minutes later, the fire was extinguished although heavy smoke continued to pour from the containers. About 12 hours after the fire, small holes were made in the containers most affected, which were then flooded via the insertion of hose nozzles. Boundary cooling continued. The door of one container emitting heavy smoke was opened and the fire inside was extinguished using four hoses. By the following morning (32 hours after detection), the containers had stopped smoking. 
The fire had started spontaneously in an open top container carrying a dangerous cargo class 4.2. The cargo, which is believed to have spilled and spontaneously combusted, was carried in 2 small tanks approx 1m in size.  A number of containers were damaged by fire. Some were flooded by water which accumulated in the hold during the fire-fighting operation. Others were also water-damaged.

In preparation to shoot nets, a 36 metre fishing vessel opened the fish net hatch, the hatch from the upper deck into the accommodation alleyway, the hatch from the upper deck to the main deck and the weathertight door between the accommodation alleyway and main deck. This allowed the crew unrestricted movement between the upper and main deck during fishing operations. The weather was described as moderate to rough and the vessel was steaming on beam seas.
The vessel was struck by a large wave which heeled her over to starboard. She was starting to return to the upright when she was hit by another wave and the vessel took on a permanent list due to the amount of sea water on her main deck net space and starboard accommodation alleyway. The list increased as water continued to wash over the vessel’s submerged starboard gunwale in way of an open net hatch and was able to progressively flood the engine room and aft accommodation via the weathertight door which had been left open. Although the crew attempted to close the net hatch on the upper deck, this did not stem the flow of water into the hull and the vessel started to sink.

Le 23 Juillet 2008 en début d'après-midi, le Sagitaire est en pêche à  20 miles dans le nord de l'île de Batz. Le mécanicien et un matelot sont sur le pont arrière, ils ramendent le  chalut tribord, endommagé au cours du trait précédent et rangé le long du pavois.

Les conditions de mer sont bonnes, mer 3 et vent de Nord-Est 18 nœuds.

Vers 14 heures, le train  de pêche croche. Le patron rejoint la plage arrière et prend les commandes des treuilles afin de virer le chalut, le second restant à la timonerie. Le mécanicien se poste  à bâbord et le matelot à tribord. Afin de passer  une bosse sur les panneaux, le matelot  est amené, à plusieurs reprises, à  grimper sur le chalut entreposé sur le pont.


Vers 14:40 heures, le mécanicien, entrant dans le pont de travail, entend le cri du matelot et s'aperçoit que ce dernier est tombé à la mer. Le mécanicien se dévêt et se jette à l'eau pour lui  porter secours.

Le second entreprend aussitôt une manœuvre de récupération d'homme à la mer. Le matelot perd rapidement connaissance et est hissé à bord avec difficulté.

Malgré les soins prodigués par le mécanicien puis par l'équipe médicale acheminée par hélicoptère, il décède environ une heure et demi plus tard.

SummaryOfEvents:
At about 18.15 hours LT on 21 January 2008, the fishing vessel ALLENA, which had been fishing near Gould Reef off the Queensland coast, began its voyage back to Bowen, Queensland. 
At 21.00 hours LT  ALENA collided with Northern Fortune, a container ship en route from Singapore to Brisbane. The fishing vessel’s bow was badly damaged but the crew was able to control the ingress of water and return the vessel to Bowen.

The accident caused the fishing boat  to sink, but all 12 fishermen were rescued.

On 7 January 2008, the UK registered and managed, Anglo-Spanish fishing vessel, SHARK, left La Coruňa in northern Spain for fishing grounds off the west coast of Ireland.  The skipper had served on board for about 1 year, but for many of the 15 crew this was their first trip in the vessel.  
At about 20.00 hours on 18 January the long-line was shot away.  The crew then rested in their cabins until they were called at 01.00 hours LT to recover it.  At about 06.30 hours LT on 19 January 2008 , thick black smoke was seen coming from one of the crew’s cabins, but the smoke detection system alarm had not sounded.  Some of the crew attempted to fight the fire but they were quickly beaten back as the thick, acrid smoke quickly spread through the accommodation area.  Although a number of watertight doors were left open near to the fire, containment was established.     Four of the crew suffered smoke inhalation.
The skipper asked a nearby Spanish fishing vessel to stand by in case they had to abandon the vessel. 
The main fire pump could not be started because the electrical control circuits had been destroyed.  The emergency manual fire pump was defective, so there was no pressurised water supply with which to fight the fire.  As the paint on the main deck started to blister, the skipper attempted to starve the fire of oxygen, but he was hampered by faulty ventilation isolating valves, and had to stuff rags around the ventilation terminals.  The rags were later removed, and the fire re-ignited. At 12.31 hours LT the skipper finally alerted the Maritime Rescue Co-ordination Centre (MRCC) at Madrid, 6 hours after the fire had started.  Emergency service support was quickly provided.  The Irish Naval vessel, LE Eithne, arrived on the scene and transferred a fire party, who extinguished the fires.  SHARK was then escorted into Killibegs for inspection.
The fire caused extensive damage throughout the accommodation area.  The investigation found numerous examples of private electrical equipment connected to the cabin supplies, and electrical cables were found to be chafed where they passed over the rough edges of the cabin bulkheads.  The fire was probably of electrical origin, caused by a faulty supply cable.  The fire detection system had been intentionally disabled, and much of the emergency equipment was in poor condition.  SHARK was also out of date for her Maritime and Coastguard Agency (MCA) Intermediate Survey.  None of the crew had the required mandatory safety course certificates, the skipper did not hold the required Certificate of Equivalent Competency and no emergency training drills had been carried out.

SummaryOfEvents: On January 18, 2008 the general cargo ship SAVA LAKE, with a cargo of metal turnings, was on her way from the port of Horsens, Denmark to port Leixoes (Portugal). At 17.30 hours (UTC) the ship was at coordinates: 50 59.5’N, 001 18.5’E when it was noticed that two crew members were missing. On the captains orders the chief officer organized a search, together with the watch engineer; both crew members were found dead at the forecastle in bosun’s room. On order from the ship's owner and in coordination with the authorities, SAVA LAKE entered the port of Dover, UK at 21.50 hours LT, where the accident was investigated.

On 18th January 2008, after departing Køge, the general cargo ship RUBYN was passing Eastbound south of Bornholm at a speed of approx. 9 knots. The chief officer had been the the OOW since midnight. At 04.30 hours LT the vessel collided with the Danish dredger Ahlsell, which was hit on its starboard side in the engine room compartment.

The OOW of RUBYN had not been aware of the dredger. There was no other crewmember on watch as a lookout.

The OOW and the duty crewmember on the dredger were engaged with regulating the depth of the the suction pipe, which had gone too deeply into the sea bed. Thus they had not observed the approaching cargo ship RUBYN.

The collision resulted in severe hull damage to the dredger. However the crew succeeded in trimming the ship to port and thus the leakages partly came over the water level.

RUBYN escorted the dredger to the port of Rønne.

SummaryOfEvents: During the night of 13th January 2008 the Greek-registered ICE PRINCE, a general cargo ship carrying 5,260 tonnes of timber for delivery to Alexandria in Egypt, got into difficulties in rough seas 35 miles off the coast of Devon. As a result of severe weather conditions the vessel began to list, shedding most of its load, and was left drifting at a 25 degree angle and without power. Twelve of the crew were airlifted to Portland by coastguard helicopter, and eight others were rescued by the Torbay lifeboat. The Maritime Coastguard Agency continued to monitor the ICE PRINCE and the French tug Abeille Liberts stood by to assist if necessary, but continuing bad weather prevented any intervention. The vessel eventually sank on 15th January 2008 at 00.45 hours LT.

Le Dimanche 06 Janvier 2008 aux environs de 17:30 heures, le chalutier « La p'tite Julie 1 » appareille du port d’Erquy pour ses lieux de pêche, situés dans le Nord de l’île d’Ouessant, avec sept personnes à bord.

A 04:46 heures le 07 Janvier ; le patron appelle le CROSS Corsen en VHF pour signaler qu’il est en train de couler. Il peut donner sa position et le nombre de personnes à bord. 
A 04:50 heures, le patron du chalutier Anthémis entre en communication en MF avec le patron de la « La p'tite Julie 1 », du même armement, qui lui précise que le bateau fait route, qu’il a une voie d’eau en train de couler par l’avant.
A 04:52 heures, après un dernier appel au CROSS Corsen en VHF, les sept membres de l’équipage sautent à la mer sans avoir pu enfiler les combinaisons de survie  ni percuter un radeau de sauvetage. 

A 07:31 heures, un hélicoptère récupère un survivant  en état d’hypothermie. Deux corps seront retrouvés dans la journée et les quatre hommes restants portés disparus.

Deux investigations sous-marines seront effectuées dans les jours suivants pour localiser  et identifier l’épave,  puis une investigation sera effectuée en juin 2008 par ROV. Elles ont pu montrer que la coque ne présentait pas  de trace de brèche ou de choc extérieur ; le panneau de débarque du poisson, sur le pont supérieur à l’avant de la timonerie, a été  trouvé ouvert avec des déformations.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On the evening of 5th January 2008 the m/v HIGH HARMONY was en route from the port of Bandar Abbas, bound for Vadinar, India. On 6th January 2008 at 07.30 hours LT, the Master of M/v High Harmony was informed by the 3rd officer that Chief Cook Mr Sequeira had not reported for duty that morning. A search was carried out on board by ship staff, but Mr. Sequeira could not be located.
AB Mr. Anton Fernando had last seen the cook on the morning of the 6th January at about 05.30 hours LT, outside his cabin. The vessel was swung around to retrace its course until it arrived at the last known position when the cook had been seen. The vessel searched the waters for about five hours but could not locate any  trace of the missing Chief Cook.
After consultation with the Management Office the Master abandoned the search and resumed passage to original destination of Vadinar.

At approximately 21.00 hous LT on 5th January 2008 the Liberian Flag container ship CMA CGM IGUACU sustained main engine failure anda small fire in the main switchboard. While transiting the North Sea from Le Havre (en route to Brazil), the vessel sustained a total loss of power. Upon further examination it was discovered that the main switchboard of the vessel had sustained a short circuit, damaging two panels of the main switchboard. The vessel was subsequently towed to Brest, France, for repairs, and resumed her voyage to Brazil on 12th Janury 2008. 
Flag State investigation was conducted by obtaining the flag state report and follow-up communications for clarification after review as necessary.

Location: Near Gangavaram Port, East coast of India
SummaryOfEvents: At aproximately 16.27 hours LT on 3rd January 2008 the m/v ZHEN HUA 22 ran aground outside Gangavaram port dredged channel, whilst making her approach to the port entrance for berthing at the iron ore berth. The vessel sustained damage to her bottom shell. Class carried otu the damage survey.

On 3rd January 2008 the M/V VANESSA, loaded with 937.4t steel billets and 2007.6t wire rods coils was in the Sea of Azov, en route from Port of Berdyansk, Ukraine to Kerch Strait when she suffered structural failure, presumably hull cracks. At the time the sea was very rough, with adverse weather conditions: wind ENE 18-23 m/sec., with air minus 9 degrees centigrade. At 00.05 hours the Master reported to Kerch Traffic Control that the bulwark (port side) was totally torn from the ship and had fallen overboard. Within two hours the ship lost its residual buoyancy, and at 02.01 hours LT the Master transmitted a distress message. The Master, seven crew members and the Pilot all lost their lives. Since the accident occurred the ship has sunk further into the sea bed.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: ON 2ND JANUARY 2008 THE M/V "SUN VENUS" EXPERIENCED MAIN ENGINE PROBLEMS AND AT APPROXIMATELY 15.55 HOURS LT REPORTED THAT SHE WAS ADRIFT APPROXIMATELY 100 MILES SOUTH OF THE ISLAND OF OAHU.

Location: Varne Bank in the English Channel
SummaryOfEvents: At 04:50 hours on 2 January 2008, the LT Cortesia ran aground on the Varne Bank sandlank in the English Channel. The ship was on route from Thames Port to the Suez Canal. At the peak of the evening high tide, at 18:58 hours, the grounded ship was freed with the aid of four tug boats. For investigation purposes, the ship was ordered to proceed to a sheltered anchorage on the coast cast approximately 10 nm northeast of Dover. No major damage as a result of the grounding was identified, which meant that the LT Cortesia upped anchor and was able to continue on its voyage at 18:00 hours on 3 January 2008.

On 1st January 2008 the m/v OCEAN LADY sank off the Spanish/North African enclave of Ceuta. The sinking occurred just hours after the vessel had been towed out of the port on fire. The OCEAN LADY had been in the port for months and had become a refuge for illegal immigrants. Police believe the tug was purposely set alight in protest at regular raids on the vessel, and was towed into the strait of Gibraltar where rescue services tackled the blaze. Despite their efforts, the tug sank in deep water eight miles off Ceuta.

Location: Off Uma Shima, Kokura-kita-ku, Kita-kyushu city, Fukuoka Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
Combined chemical and oil tanker Golden Georgia (registered Panama, 9597 gt, built 1996), with 22 crews, ran aground on the shallows off Uma Shima, Kokura-kita-ku, Kita-kyushu city, Fukuoka Prefecture, Japan.
Vessel was refloated by tugs.  No water ingress or oil spill was found.
Vessel landed heavily alongside berth and sustained underwater hull damage resulting in internal flooding of the engine room.

Location: ALONGSIDE TO THE ADM-AMA DOCK IN MISSISSIPPI RIVER
SummaryOfEvents:
A 17.00 HOURS LT ON 26TH DECEMBER 2007 THE BULK CARRIER "AGIOS LOUKAS" WAS AT LOADING BERTH WHEN SHE WAS STRUCK ON HER STARBOARD SIDE BY THE M/V "GEMINI".
THE TUG"TAKO CHALLENGER" WAS PUSHING ON ADM RIG"GEMINI" AND BARGE"MED 2405" AND APPROACHED M/v "AGIOS LOUKAS" TOO FAST.
DAMAGE WAS SUSTAINED TO "AGIOS LOUKAS"'S STARBOARD BRIDGE WING AND STARBOARD HULL IN WAY OF NO.6 AND NO.7 HOLDS.
ClassificationSociety1: Polski Rejestr Statkow (Polish Register of Shipping) (PRS)

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
On 25th December 2007 at 04.19 hours LT the Korean-registered tanker Eastern Bright was under way from Kwangyang, Korea to Taiwan, China but went missing after requesting assistance via VHF CH16, and the vessel was found sunk in the coastal waters of Korea.
Eastern Bright had been loading Nitric Acid(about 2,000MT) in a heavy sea.
The Korean Coast Guard, Navy and Air force sent out many patrol ships and airplanes in rescue operations, but only dead bodies were found.
The Korean Authorities are still trying to find the cause of the accident.

SOLASStatus: SEISHO MARU: Unknown/unspecified, YUAN DA No. 2: SOLAS
Location: In Kanmon Straight, Yamaguchi Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
At 21.46 hours LT on 23rd December 2007 general cargo ships Yuan Da No.2 (registered Cambodia, 1,299 GRT, built 1984) and Seisho Maru (registered Japan, 1,767 GRT, built 1998) collided in Kanmon Straight, Yamaguchi Prefecture, Japan.
Yuan Da No.2 sustained damage to its bulbous bow.
Seisho Maru sustained cracking damage, resulting in water ingress in the bow.

On 20th December 2007 the vessel TOR PRIMULA collided with the vessel BRAGA as it was trying to overtake her in the narrow waters near Vlissingen. There had been radio contact between the ships, but there was no agreement as to how the TOR PRIMULA should pass the BRAGA. A collision occurred at 04.16 LT as the bow and bulbous bow of TOR PRIMULA hit the stern of BRAGA. TOR PRIMULA recieved no damages, but the BRAGA suffered a leak in the aft peak tank.

SOLASStatus: FLYING PHANTOM: Unknown/unspecified, RED JASMINE: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: On 19th December 2007 the tug FLYNG PHANTOM was assisting the bulk carrier Red Jasmine as a bow tug during a transit of the River Clyde in thick fog when she capsized and sank at 18.00 hours LT.  Three of the tug's four crew were lost; only the tug mate managed to escape from the tug's wheelhouse and was subsequently rescued.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On Wednesday 19th December 2007 at 01.23 hours LT, a fire started in the engine room of the "Vasco da Gama" when she was arriving at the port of Jebel Ali.
The fire was caused by a leak on the fuel oil line that delivers fuel oil to the port side main engine.  The fire was extinghuished by releasing CO2 into the engine room. The engine room suffered severe damages. No casualties, however one crew member broke his leg when rushing downstairs in the vessel's accomodation area.

ON 18TH DECEMBER 2007 AT 15.40 HOURS LT, IN POSITION 37º42 N, 024º19E, A SUDDEN UNUSUAL AND PERSISTENT NOISE WAS HEARD FROM THE MAIN ENGINE OF THE BULK CARRIER MASTER DAVIDOV. THE CHIEF ENGINEER IMMEDIATELY STOPPED THE ENGINE. THE VESSEL ANCHORED AND
WAS TOWED TO PIRAEUS.
AFTER INSPECTIONS THE FOLLOWING WAS FOUND: 1st IDLE GEAR, 2nd IDLE GEAR, CAM SHAFT GEAR DAMAGED.

At around 13:50 hours on 17 December 2007, the bulk carrier Senanur Cebi, sailing under the Turkish flag, moored at the Elbe port in Brunsbüttel. The berthing manoeuvre was supported by the tugs Bugsier 11 and Bugsier 12. The first acted as stern tug. The Senanur Cebi berthed with the starboard side. At the time of the accident there was an ebb tide running at approximately 1.5 to 2 kn.
While the towing connection to Bugsier 11 was singled up, a large section of the messenger line which was secured to the towing cable fell into the water. This line was picked up by and wound around the Senanur Cebi controllable pitch propeller which was running at Zero pitch. Subsequently the entire towing cable was torn off the tug. A member of the tug’s crew was severely injured on this left leg by the tripping line tuning out last.

A collision  occurred at about  22.52 hours LT on the 15th of December 2007, between a Liberian Chemical Tanker vessel “FORMOSA  TEN”, proceeding from Taiwan, China to MOKPO in Korea, and a local fishing vessel “ZHEFENGYU 11017”. The fishing boat sank and 19 crew members were lost. A further crew member was rescued.

Location: Off Mukuchijima Lighthouse, Kurashiki City, Okayama Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents: At 14.18 hours LT on 15th December 2007 the general cargo ship Dongjin Yokohama (registered Korea, 2448 GRT, built 1991), ran aground on the shallows off Mukuchijima Lighthouse, Kurashiki City, Okayama Prefecture, Japan. There were 14 crew members on board (8 Koreans including the Captain, 4 Chinese and 2 Myanmarese). The vessel was later refloated by tugs, but had sustained  denting and scratching, and a hole had been made in its underside.
The FRC was being launched for a routine drill. Swung out over the ships side, the release hook was cocked, and shortly afterwards the boat dropped 8 metres to the water, injuring three crew members

Location: In Kashiwazaki Port, Niigata Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
On 14th December 2007 the general cargo ship Hirokichi (registered Georgia, 1,550 GRT, built 1981), and manned by 8 Chinese crew members, ran aground in heavy weather at 05.05 hours LT in the shallows of Kashiwazaki Port, Niigata Prefecture, Japan.
The vessel was subsequntly refloated by a tug. There was no water ingress or oil spill.

On 13th December 2007 the passenger Ro/Ro vessel Stena Jutlandica was en route from Göteborg, Sweden to Frederikshavn, Denmark. At 09.25 hours LT a crew member who was working on a moveable platform deck moved backwards without realising how close he was to the end of the deck, and fell about 3 metres onto the deck below. He was evacuated to hospital by helicopter. The subsequent investigation pointed out the importance of always using a safety guard when working on levels where there is a risk of falling.

ON 13TH DECEMBER 2007 THE M/V JI MEI LONG WAS 9.0 KNOTS FULL SPEED AHEAD ON THE PARANA RIVER WHEN THE PILOT ORDERED THAT THE COURSE BE CHANGED FROM "000" TO "350".  AT 02.44 HOURS LT THE SHIP’S SPEED SUDDENLY REDUCED TO 0 KNOTS, AND THE VESSEL WAS  FOUND TO BE GROUNDED. THE CREW THEN FOLLOWED STEP BY STEP INSTRUCTIONS FOR ‘EMERGENCY PLAN FOR GROUNDING’. AFTER THE SHIP RAN AGROUND ALL MACHINES AND TANKS WERE CHECKED AND FOUND TO BE IN NORMAL CONDITION. AT THE PILOT'S ORDERS THEY USED ME/FULL ASTERN AND FULL RUDDER PORT, STARBOARD, AND THE SHIP REFLOATED AFTER SIX HOURS WITHOUT EXTERNAL ASSISTANCE AND WITHOUT DISCHARGING THE BALLAST WATER.
AFTER REFLOATING ALL EQUIPMENT WAS CHECKED AND TANKS FOUND TO BE IN GOOD CONDITION.

Location: Water of Zhou Shan Islands in China
SummaryOfEvents: A collision accident occurred at about  2014 hours local time (Beijing time) , the 12th of Dec 2007, between a Cyprus Bulk vessel SPITHA proceeding from Zhoushan to Zhangjiagang and a local fishing vessel “ZHEPUYU 71090” which was owned by Xu Yongfa . The accident caused the fishing boat sunk, 6 fishermen were missed or died.

At approximately 18.28 hours LT on 12th December 2007, the M/V BREEZE, Liberian flag, collided with M/V MINGHUI No.59 at the position of 30°33.1′N/124°10.5′E (near Y19 light buoy of Yangtze River). IAs a result of the collision, the M/V MINGHUI NO.59 sank.
While docking in the ferry berth in Spodsbjerg, the ferry hit the berth and the bow port was slightly damaged. The bow port was twisted approximately 3-4 cm out of position.

At about 04.50 hours on 11 December 2007, at  24˚ 27.3’ N/119˚ 13.6’ E, the fishing boat “MIN HUI YU 0022” collided with the northbound M/V “APL SEATTLE” flying the Liberian flag. The collision led to the sinking of the fishing boat “MIN HUI YU 0022”.  At 06.18 hours, six crew members were rescued by the fishing boat  from the same village. The accident did not cause injury or death or sea pollution.
On 10th December 2007 the general cargo vessel FENIX was off the east coast of Brazil when it was discovered that first engineer, MR. STEPHEN CASARIEGO MORE, was missing, assumed lost.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: On 10th December 2007 the m/v SILVER FJORD was en route to Gothenburg  loaded with 1,000 tonnes of frozen fish, and proceeding to Slite with a five-10 degrees starboard list as a result of water ingress. The vessel was approximately six nautical miles off Slite and proceeding under her own power, although extra pumps were placed onboard. A pilot came on board and a rescue vessel was called to assist. The weather on scene was calm with winds: southerly, four m/s.

On 9th December 2007, en route from Geneva (Italy) to Rotterdam (Netherlands) the loaded general cargo vesel STROPUS  encountered heavy weather conditions in the English Channel - SW storm force 10, with sea waves reaching 10 m.  At 11.25 hours LT the crew found that the connection rod between PS steering machine and rudder stock of the central rudder was damaged. At about 13.40 hours LT the ship lost her manoeuvraibility due to failure of the PS steering machine. At 14.24 hours LT the master sent out a distress alert and contacted MRCC Corsen (France). 8 crew members were evacuated from the vessel by helicopter. Finaly, on 11th December 2007 the vessel was towed to the port of Falmouth (UK) with the remaining 4 crewmembers on board.

On 9th December 2007 the container ship MSC MAGALI was approaching Salvador berth with a local pilot onboard. The vessel drifted off course due  to the effects of the ebb tide and  delays in making fast the tugs, and consequently grounded on soft mud when making a turn around the breakwater. The vessel refloated by her own during the next high ide. There was no human injury, damage to vessel or cargo and no pollution.

SOLASStatus: LU SHUI JI 959: Unknown/unspecified, WAVE VENTURE: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: Vessel was approaching a bend in the river requiring an alteration of course to port. A self propelled barge was overtaking to starboard, and as the vessel altered course the stern approached the barge. Whistle signals were sounded, and the vessel used bow and azimuth thrusters to move the ship bodily to port. However, the vessels collided. The barge suffered a bent bollard, and the ship an indent to the plating 1 m above the waterline, 6m long, and opening the hull over a distance of 60cm.

SOLASStatus: MSC PRESTIGE: Unknown/unspecified, SAMCO EUROPE: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: On Friday 7 December 2007, at 23:47 hours TU, French VLCC Samco Europe and Container ship MSC prestige, Flying panama flag, have been involved in a collision 16  NM east-south-east of “Bab el Mandeb”.

Location: At Onomichi-Itozaki Port, Onomichi City, Hiroshima Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents: On 7th December 2007 the general cargo ship Denitza (registered Bolivia, 1,587 GRT), was berthing at Onomichi-Itozaki Port, Onomichi City, Hiroshima Prefecture, Japan. At 13.25 hours LT, whilst the vessel was listing to port, a Japanese worker who was discharging cargo became caught under the loaded timber, and subsequently died.

SOLASStatus: Hebei Spirit: SOLAS, HEBEI SPIRIT: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
On 6th December 2007  the Korean registered tug boats Samsung T-5 and Samho T-3 left the port of Incheon, Korea for the port of Kohyen, Korea,  towing crane barge Samsung 1.
Whilst they were navigating in inclement weather near the port of Daesan, the towing line between Samsung T-5 and Samsung 1 was cut, and Samsung 1 was pushed by strong winds toward  Hebei Spirit.
The Hong Kong registered oil tanker Hebei Spirit was at anchor near the pilot station of the port of Daesan.
At 07.06 LT on 7 December 2007, Samsung 1 and Hebei Spirit collided 7 miles off the Gadaeam lighthouse in Korea in the direction of 033º, at position 36º 52' 07" N - 126º 03' 07" E.
- The Hebei Spirit suffered holes in the portside shell plate of No. 1,3,5 cargo oil tanks and spilled crude oil of approximately 12,547㎘ into the sea.

On 6th December 2007 at 20.24 LT, the ferry waiting for delayed out bound vessel was caught by the wind, moving her bodily to starboard. Despite the master's best efforts to move the vessel to port, the vessel struck a navigation pile, bending it from the vertical by about 30 degrees.

After discharging her cargo of bulk maize, Captain Stamos left the port of Volos in ballast condition, between 14.00 and 14.30 on December 5th 2007. 
On board the vessel there was a tug boat (named:R/K Achilleas) and a pilot assisting the vessel to make the neccesary manoeuvres inside the port. As the vessel was moving backwards with the assistance of the tug Achilleas, strong winds caused her to drift, and her starboard side touched the small tug boat Pillon that was moored at the side of the dock. 
The damage caused to the tug Pillon was only a small dent on her starboard side shell above the water line, and no injuries were caused to the crew of the tug or our vessel's crew. 
Our vessel then anchored to the outer anchorage of Volos port and the Master was taken ashore to the port authorities to testify about this incident. 
The port authorities came onboard and inspected our vessel in order to see if any damage had been caused by the minor collision, and after concluding that there was none, allowed the vessel to sail to her destination of Yuzny/Ukraine.

The  187m long ro ro passenger ship Maersk Delft entered the arrival harbour and was designated a berth, which had to approached stern first and made fast port side alongside. Because of the 40 Knot winds, which would be on the starboard beam while approaching the berth, a tug was made fast forward. During the berthing operation, while the stern was being manoeuvred away from a dolphin, which was on the starboard quarter, and the tug pulling on the bow, the port quarter fell down faster than desired and the belting made contact with the forward edge of a fender.  A stiffening bracket inside the belting punctured the hull in the way of the port steering gear compartment, causing a tear of 300mm x 60mm. The vessel was taken out of class while repairs were affected. After approval of the repairs by Lloyds and MCA, the vessel sailed 8 hours after the accident.

The master recommended that the vessel should be stopped short of the dolphin in adverse weather to achieve a more controlled landing alongside. 

The harbour authority will be removing the dolphin the following year.
On 4th December 2007 the passenger vessel EXPRESS 14 was at open sea when a crew member was reported missing.  The report was confirmed at 17.30 hours LT, and the man was assumed lost at sea.
On 4th December 2007 the roro cargo ship ZAHRA III experienced engine failure, and  drifted towards Hanish Sughra, where she stranded at 08:30 hours LT.

RENEWED ALL CYLINDER PISTON RINGS, PISTON CROWN FOR MAIN ENGINE 1,2,3,5 AND 6, RENEWED PISTON SKIRT FOR NO.1 AND NO.4 AND RENEWED CYLINDER LINER FOR NO.4 CYLINDER AT HAWAII, UNDER SUPERVISION OF MAKER`S SERVICE ENGINEER AND CARRIED OUT MACHINERY OCCASIONAL SURVEY BY CLASS.
RENEWED ALL CYLINDER PISTON RINGS, PISTON CROWN AND CYLINDER LINER AT ANCHORAGE OF YURA, JAPAN UNDER SUPERVISION OF MAKER`S SERVICE ENGINER AND CARRIED OUT MACHINERY SURVEY BY CLASS AS A RESULT OF THE INCIDENT.

Small motorboat with 12 persons on board is sighted. Mv Fairpartner stops to rescue refugees on board. Gangway is lowered and small motorboat approaching. Near gangway small motorboat capsizes, two persons can be rescues. MOB boat is lowered, but no other persons can be saved.

On the 3rd of December, 2007 approx. at 0600 hrs L.T./I.S.T., M.F.V. “BRAHMMAM” was reportedly trawling in the designated fishing area in the Arabian Sea around SAKTHI KULANGAR, a small fishing harbour near Kollam Port, Kerala, India, with all her trawls out. While the Fishing Vessel was engaged in the fishing activity in the area, a deep sea vessel M.V. “MIAMI”, stated to be a bulk carrier, who was on her southerly course, collided with M.F.V. “BRAHMMAM”, approx. at 0710 hrs L.T./I.S.T., on her stbd. side near stern at a position LAT. 08 53.374’ N and LONG. 75 47.30’ E. M.V. “MIAMI”, after making “violent encounter” with the vessel, simply continued on her sea passage without reporting the incident to the Authorities.

At 13.52 hours LT on 2nd December 2007 the ENDEAVOUR RIVER grounded in Gladstone harbour during a berthing attempt, colliding with and destroying A1 beacon at the entrance to the Auckland Channel. The ship was not seriously damaged during the grounding and there was no pollution.

At approximately 03:30 hours, on the morning of 02 December 2007, on board the Irish registered ship " Arklow Willow" at Kings Dock, Swansea, a Trainee Cadet went missing while on duty. Approximately three days later on 05 December 2007 his body was recovered from the dock.

A post mortem examination found that the cause of death was drowning.

Location: from Kattegat to the port Grenaa
SummaryOfEvents:
The 27½ foot fishing vessel IDA, that had passed through essential alterations and was equipped with relatively heavy gear for trawling, was trawling for soles 10 – 12 nm South-east of Grenaa.

The skipper was alone on board.

At approximately 0300 the skipper began sailing back to Grenaa, which he told his colleague on board another fishing vessel in the same area.

The fishing vessel disappeared during the passage back to Grenaa, and neither the skipper nor the vessel has been found.

Location: 20 Miles of La Pointe du Touquet
SummaryOfEvents:
Le vendredi 30 Novembre 2007 vers 14:00 heures, le patron du chalutier « Mon bijou » s’aperçoit, en remontant son chalut, que celui-ci a des avaries. Pour terminer sa marée, il fait filer un autre  chalut de l’enrouleur triple. Après avoir trié le poisson, l’équipage élonge une partie du chalut à réparer dans l’entrepont couvert. Le bourrelet empêche de fermer la porte coulissante située entre l’entrepont couvert et l’entrepont découvert, ainsi que la porte de la rampe arrière. 


Le Mon Bijou traîne, dans le « Trou du Vergoyer » en suivant un cap entre le 030° et 060° à la vitesse de 4 nœuds, mer de l’arrière avec des vents de force 5 à 6.

Soudainement le chalutier ralentit, commence à vibrer et stoppe. Le patron diminue le nombre de tours du moteur et demande à son équipage  d’enrouler rapidement  le chalut qui vient d’être réparé, afin de pouvoir virer le chalut qui est à l’eau.

Sous la tension de la fune bâbord, le chalutier vient sur la gauche et embarque par-dessus le pavois bâbord arrière un premier paquet de mer qui n’entre pas dans l’entrepont couvert. Le chalutier s’enfonce de l’arrière et prend une gîte de plus en plus importante sur bâbord. Les paquets de mer suivant entre dans l’entrepont  couvert. Rapidement le phénomène s’accentue.

Le patron s’étant rendu compte de la situation, commence à dévirer les funes. L’équipage voyant que l’eau recouvre  complètement  le treuil bâbord, monte à la passerelle. 

Le radeau de sauvetage est lancé à l’eau. Le patron  déclenche l’alerte  au moyen de la VHF et de la BLU. Le chalutier gîtant et s’enfonçant  de l’arrière  de plus en plus, l’équipage  se jette à l’eau et embarque  dans le radeau de sauvetage. Il manque un matelot.

Les fusées sont lancées. Une heure après, l’équipage  voit arriver vers lui un cargo puis un second. Deux hélicoptères s’approchent. Trois matelots sont évacués par hélicoptère  belge, Les autres attendent l’arrivée du canot de sauvetage de Boulogne-sur-Mer qui les prendra à son bord. 

Après avoir entrepris des recherches pour retrouver le matelot disparu, la météorologie se dégradant, le canot de sauvetage fait route vers Boulogne-sur-Mer pour débarquer les trois rescapés. Malgré la mise en place par le CROSS Gris-nez d’importants moyens de secours, l’Homme porté manquant n’a pu être retrouvé.

Son corps découvert trois jours plus tard sur la plage de Malo-les-Bains.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents: On 30th November 2007 the m/v NAMHAE GAS was off the Queensland coast when she collided with the Australian fishing vessel Rexandra at 00.36 hours LT. The REXANDRA was damaged in the collision but made her way safely back to harbour. There were no injuries and no pollution.
On 29th November 2007 the dredger KAISHU was in the area of Palm Island, Dubai when she grounded at point of course change on the river, probably as a result of speeding.

ON THE MORNING OF 28TH NOVEMBER 2007 WHILST THE MV CARNIVAL ECSTASY WAS AT SEA, THE NURSE WAS CALLED TO ONE OF THE CABINS. SHE FOUND A PASSENGER UNCONSCIOUS IN THE BATHROOM, AND CALLED FOR ASSISTANCE FROM THE REST OF THE MEDICAL TEAM. CPR WAS PERFORMED FOR SEVERAL MIINUTES BUT THE DOCTOR DECLARED THE PATIENT DEAD. THE BODY WAS TAKEN TO THE INFIRMARY.

InitialEvent: BLACK- OUT OCCURRED DUE TO SHORT CIRCUIT IN MAIN SWITH BOARD WITH RESULT TO LOSS OF MAIN POWER (SEE SUMMARY OF EVENTS)
SummaryOfEvents:
While transiting Savannah River on 27/11/07 and at about 00:34 hours LT, vessel had a blackout as a result of loss of mains power. The emergency power came on.
At 00:42 hrs the vessel dropped the port anchor and stopped. At about 00:55 the strong current and winds pivoted the vessel around anchor, causing port quarter section of hull to contact bottom to the port bank of the river. 
Following the pilot’s orders two tugboats arrived. At 01:15 and 01:25; T/B Cynthia and T/B Edward Moran fastened at vessel's bow and stern to assist the vessel to come out from the port side so as not to impede local traffic. 
Two more tugboats assisted from the vessel port side, pushing and holding the vessel to the starboard side of the river, and the situation was brought under control. All essential systems remained operational. All the necessary checks and tests were carried out and no damage was identified. 
No sign of spillage or danger of spillage notified. 
At 12:38 anchor chain cut off and let go into the water proceeding to LNG terminal with the assistance of the two tugboats. 
At 13:18 first line ashore. At 15:20 fasted at LNG terminal (2+2). 
Two Tugboats remained pushing as per C.O.T.P. order.

SummaryOfEvents:
CONTEXTO Y CIRCUNSTANCIAS EN QUE OCURRIÓ
                                                     EL SINIESTRO” 


El B/T Liberiano “High Endeavour”, es una nave tanquera de doble casco,  construida el año 2004, la cual ya  había prestado servicios de  transporte de hidrocarburos, recalando a los Puertos de Iquique, Antofagasta y Quintero, en los años 2005 y 2007.
Su Armador corresponde a una compañía que opera un número importante de naves, la cuál en este viaje debió por asuntos comerciales, cambiar el puerto de desembarque de la carga, desde Quintero a San Vicente, distantes aproximadamente a un día de navegación.

La travesía a este nuevo puerto, al igual que la maniobra de ingreso, al atraque al terminal “C” de Enap Refinerías Bío Bío, se realizó sin novedad, a pesar de que como se constataría mas tarde, la nave no contaba con una  carta náutica de  escala apropiada para graficar las situaciones y llevar un control adecuado de la derrota de entrada y salida al puerto,

El 10 de Noviembre de 2007, habiendo terminado la descarga y  faenas de desamarrado  del terminal, inició la navegación en demanda del canalizo de salida del dispositivo de separación de tráfico para salir de la bahía. Posterior a la largada de remolcadores y producido ya el desembarco del Práctico del Puerto, tocó fondo en el Bajo “Roca Villa de Burdeos”, el cual está a estribor del canalizo de salida y demarcado con una baliza luminosa lateral, según los estándares internacionales de balizamiento. 

El equipo de puente, no siguió las recomendaciones del derrotero, ni las indicadas en  otras publicaciones náuticas, como tampoco las que habría dado el  Práctico, respecto a la navegación para alcanzar el Esquema  de Separación de Tráfico, ya que después que éste desembarcó la nave se dispusieron cambios de rumbo sucesivos que sumados a las condiciones de viento reinantes, la llevaron a estribor, hasta tocar fondo fuera del mencionado esquema.

Producto del accidente, no se registraron lesiones a personas, ni contaminación al medio ambiente marino y los daños se circunscribieron a  la obra viva, con abolladuras y fracturas de casco, comprometiendo la integridad de 3 estanques de lastre, al quedar comunicados con el mar. 

La estabilidad de la nave no fué afectada gravemente, pero en consideración a la magnitud de los daños, debió ser sometida a reparaciones en dique, previo a reiniciar actividades comerciales.

SummaryOfEvents:
At about 21.40 hours LT on 27th October 2007, one of the Danish shore service technicians working onboard mv “APL Jade”  met with a fatal accident. The incident occurred while the vessel was in the Port of Bremerhaven, Germany. While working inside the main engine liner, the victim was severely scalded by the hot main engine jacket cooling water. The victim was then taken to the hospital ashore for medical treatment but succumbed to his injuries the next day.

Investigations revealed that the direct cause of the accident was due to the accidental opening of the inlet valve by his colleague. The shore technicians were working on the same main engine liner. 

Cause of the Incident	  
The root cause of the incident was failure to comply with the shipboard safety management practices while personnel were working inside the liner. The vessel failed to conduct Risk Assessment and did not implement the “Lockout / Tagout” system. The inlet valve was not isolated and locked while the victim was working inside the liner.

SummaryOfEvents:
In October 2007, the MV USL Hawlk was sailing from Brisbane, Australia to Hong Kong, China.
On the 18 October, at 09:48 hours (local time), the main engine failed and a black out occurred. The ship was not under command and drifting.

First the engine room staff thought the failure was owing to a broken stud of the fuel injector, later it became clear that the damage was more extensive.

The office was informed and communication was set up with the owners, insurance and all other parties involved.

On the 20 October, around 20:40 hours (local time), an ocean tug arrived in position and towed the ship safely to a shipyard in Cebu in the Philippines. Repairs were carried out from the 25 October till the 10 November 2007.

The crew responded well taking the circumstances into consideration.

Location: Off the South East coast of Ireland
SummaryOfEvents:
On Wednesday 17 October 2007, a crewman fell overboard from the MFV Alma Amy and drowned in an area off the Southeast of the Wexford coast.
The cause of death was determined by post mortem examination as being due to cardiorespiratory arrest secondary to drowning.

Location: Amazonas River, close to Pedreiras Island.
SummaryOfEvents:
On October 16th 2007, the Bulk carrier ship CSK UNITY, IMO Nr 9077226, flag Singapore, call sign 9VPU, 38371 dwt, 36074 gt, built January 1995, with 25 crew, ran aground near Pedreiras Island, Amazon River, latitude 00º 18, 306 N and longitude 050º 38,808 W, at 04.37 hours local time, when travelling from Porto Trombetas harbour (Brazil) to Corpus Christi, Texas - USA.
The vessel was refloated on October 22nd 2007 at 10.09 hours LT using her own machines and with tugboat help, after trying to be refloated with the aid of their own machines without success three times. During the grounding and refloating operations no injury and no pollution (no oil spill ) were observed.

On 15th October 2007 at 11.18 hours LT the Stena Voyager, a large catamaran, was about 30 minutes into its Irish Sea crossing when the fire alarm sounded in No 1 gas turbine engine (LM 2500) enclosure located in the port hull/pontoon.  The engineer, who was located on the bridge immediately viewed the enclosure and confirmed that there was a small but discernible flash indicating a fire.  The enclosure UV sensors picked up the fire and the automatic shut down and fire extinguishing process activated.  The engine was shut down, and the fuel, ventilation, air intake and exhaust systems were isolated.  The CO2 system was discharged into the enclosure and the fire was seen to die down and be extinguished.  In the meantime the captain alerted the passengers, and as a precaution they were issued with lifejackets.  The fire team confirmed that the fire was out - the whole fire incident lasted about 2 minutes.  It was decided to return to the departure port on the starboard hull engines.  The passengers were stood down from emergency stations a short time later.

The affected engine had its power turbine replaced as part of the lifed programme of components the previous day. However the General Electric contractors were used to dealing with aero engines which do not have a powere turbine fitted as this one does.   This trip was the first since the change.  On investigation it was found that the module, power turbine channel plate recess had some oil residue in it that was soaked up by the power turbine to exhaust lagging.  It was also found that there was a hot gas leak from the power turbine to piston seal, exhaust joint that heated up the lagging and ignited the oil that was soaked in it.  There was no damage except for a small scorch mark identifying the source of the gas leak.  The contractors attended the vessel and rectified the leak and the lagging has been replaced.  All auto drains have been cleaned and checked to ensure oil that oil leakage is directed to the drain tank as designed.

At 0930, 13th, Oct., 2007, JING BO HU, mooring at 19# anchorage of Zhanjiang port, Guangdong Province, China, which its first middle tank and second first middle tank happened explosion, causing damage to its tank, bow and causing 5 crewmembers light injury, furthermore, 68.8 tons cargo diesel leaked in sea.

Location: In Mikawa Port, Aichi Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents:
On 12th October 2007 at 15.50 LT vehicle carrier Maersk Welkin (registered Singapore, 52,691 gt, built 2006), with 25 crews (1 Singaporean, 7 Indians, 8 Chinese, 8 Filipinos and 1 Malaysian), ran aground on the shallows in Mikawa Port, Aichi Prefecture, Japan. 
She was refloated by tugs.  No water ingress, oil spill or personal injury was reported.

Location: Guanabara Bay, Rio de Janeiro Harbour, accsess chanell to Exxon Mobill´s Terminal
SummaryOfEvents: On 12th October 2007 at 13.20 hours LT the Chemical / Oil Products Tanker ship CHEMBULK SAVANNAH, IMO nr 9248461, call sign V7DI3, built January 2002, 24404 DWT, 15148 GT, with 26 crew, was navigating for the access channel to the terminal of Movable Exxon when it collided with the buoy of demarcation of the channel, stranding soon afterwards. The vessel was refloated on the same day, with the help of two tugboats. No injuries were sustained, nor pollution (oil spill)observed during the collision with the buoy, grounding and refloating operations. The ship was unfit to proceed due to structural propeller damage, and remained waiting for repair.

InitialEvent: VESSEL DIVERTED FROM VOYAGE TO PICK UP TECHNICIAN TO RECTIFY ELECTRICAL PROBLEM
SummaryOfEvents: ON 12TH OCTOBER 2007 THE CONTAINER SHIP 'SONIA' WAS PROCEEDING FROM KAOHSIUNG TO MELBOURNE, 0540mt AT LAT 04º38N, LONG 135º39E., WHEN THE POWER FROM THE MAIN SHIPBOARD GENERATORS WAS DISRUPTED DUE TO AN ELECTRICAL FAULT. DUE TO MALFUNCTIONING  OF THE AVR, IT WAS NOT POSSIBLE FOR PARALLEL OPERATION OF THE OTHER GENERATOR. THE VESSEL WAS STOPPED FOR ABOUT 17 HOURS, DURING WHICH THE SHIP STAFF LOCATED AND REPAIRED THE FAULT ON AVR FOR NO.1 AUXILIARY ENGINE. IN KEEPING WITH THE COMPANY SAFETY POLICY, COMPETENT SERVICE TECHNICIANS WERE EMBARKED AT THE PORT OF LAE, PAPUA NEW GUINEA ON 18th OCTOBER 2007 TO THOROUGHLY CHECK AND CARRY OUT THE REQUIRED SERVICE TO THE ELECTRICAL SYSTEM OF THE SHIP. THE VESSEL RESUMED HER VOYAGE TO MELBOURNE WITH THE SERVICE TECHNICIANS ON BOARD. THERE WAS NO STRUCTURAL DAMAGE, CREW INJURY OR POLLUTION DURING THIS ENTIRE PERIOD.
On 10th October 2007 at 20.15 hours LT, the electrical Officer, MR. CIPRIANO P.J. GONSALVES, who had been working on the ship's elevator, was found dead.

Location: Shanghai Baoshan wharf no.14 Shanghai port
SummaryOfEvents: At 1415hrs, On 9th Oct 2007, while MV JIANG Ning (Port registry NANJING, IMO No. 9425289, Owner ZHENJIANG SHIPPING CO. LTD., LOA 99.98m, Breadth 16.6m, Depth 8.4m, 4259GT, Dry Cargo Ship) handling for berthing Shanghai Baoshan wharf berth no.6, collided MV PLATINUM DIAMOND mid part of port side with angle about 60 degree. This caused some parts of the two ships indented and deformed respectively.

A collision accident occurred at about 1537 hours local time (Beijing time) , the 7th of OCT 2007, between a PANAMA Container  vessel QI YUN HE and a China  Bulk  vessel HUA  TONG 9. The accident caused HUA  TONG  9 vessels partially destroyed but all the crew were safe .

SummaryOfEvents:
General Cargo Ship Grand Free (registered Cambodia, 648 gt, built 1987), with 7 crew (Chinese), and Tug Boat Shiroyama Maru (19 gt), towing a barge, with 2 crew (Japanese), were in collision off Ushi Shima, Kagawa Prefecture, Japan.
Grand Free sank and a little oil spill was reported.  All crew members on board both ships were unharmed.

SummaryOfEvents: Due to heavy flood in the engine room, the ship was badly trimmed by the storm, going down bodily by the stem at a very fast rate.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:
On 4th October 2007 at 16:30hrs the m/v Panamax Peppou had departed from San Lorenzo port, T6 terminal, after loading 43076mt S.B.M. with destination to N.Europe, with sailing draughts of 10.33mtr f.w even keel..
During the navigation through the Parana river waters and the River plate the vessel was assisted by the river pilots.
On 5th October 2007 at 13:05hrs when proceeding from Emilio mitre channel to the Buenos Aires approach channel the vessel touched bottom (ran aground) at km 12 of the Buenos Aires approach channel, right side. 
At the time of the incident, the captain was on duty and assisting the navigation. Several unsuccessful attempts to refloat were carried out. Soundings around the vessel showed that the vessel was standing at her forward section about 30mts on starboard side.
At 17:30hrs the re-floating attempts where suspended waiting for H.W tide.
At 23:30hrs the re-floating maneuverings where resumed during favourable tide.
On 8th October at 00:30hrs the vessel was re-floated and Coast Guard authorised navigation to Zona Comun for further inspection at anchorage, and the vessel anchored at 03.10hours LT.
At 03:20hrs PSC boarded the vessel and joint survey with   Technical Inspector of P&I Club representative commenced.
All water ballast and bunker tanks together with confferdams and hold bilge water sounded and soundings compared with previous records with satisfactory results.
F.P.T.were inspected internally and no any damage observed and no evidence of water ingress was detected. Steering equipment was also tested with satisfactory results. No damage to vessel, cargo or environmental was observed and/or reported. Accordingly the vessel was authorised to resume navigation to destination port .

ShipsInvolved: BLITHE SPIRIT (-), LADY HAMILTON OF HEPFORD (-)
SOLASStatus: BLITHE SPIRIT: Unknown/unspecified, LADY HAMILTON OF HEPFORD: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
At approximately 06:00 hrs on 3 October 2007, Lady Hamilton of Helford left the Helford River and headed across Falmouth Bay at 6 knots towards the ‘Old Wall’ fishing grounds. Her skipper was on watch in the wheelhouse while the ship’s two deckhands slept. At approximately 06:15, Blithe Spirit left Falmouth and headed south towards the Manacles at a speed of between 18 and 26 knots. Shortly after leaving the harbour, the skipper of Blithe Spirit, who was operating single handed, altered course to port to avoid a cluster of unidentified lights ahead of him. Once steady on his new course, with the way ahead apparently clear, he sat down to rest.
 At approximately 06:22 hrs, Blithe Spirit and Lady Hamilton of Helford collided. The crew of Lady Hamilton of Helford were thrown to the deck and covered in debris. Lady Hamilton of Helford was holed above and below the waterline and started to rapidly take on water. Her skipper used a mobile phone to inform the coastguard while his crew launched a liferaft. The liferaft did not fully inflate and was unusable. Fortunately, a local pilot boat quickly arrived on the scene and recovered the skipper and his crew. The damaged ship was taken in tow but sank at 06:46 hrs. When the two ships collided, the skipper of Blithe Spirit hit his head on a
chart plotter on impact before landing on the deck of his boat. It would appear that he then lost consciousness for a short period. After coming to, Blithe Spirit’s skipper took the boat back to Falmouth, arriving there at about 07:15 hrs.

Location: 50 nautical miles from Camaleão island,  Vila Augusto Montenegro - Urucurituba City, Amazonas State,
SummaryOfEvents:
On 2nd October 2007 at 23.04 hours LT, the oil products tanker ship (oil carrier) LAVRAS, IMO Nr 8301826, flag Brazil, call sign PPSG, 29995 dwt, built 1992, with 33 crew and 2 pilots on board, ran aground near Urucurituba City, Amazonas State, Latitude 02º 47.307' S and Longitude 057º 49.932' W.
The ship was refloated with the assistance of two tugboats on October 4th, at 10.30 hours LT. During the grounding and refloating operations no injuries were sustained or pollution (no oil spill ) observed. After  inspection of the Society DNV  to attest the normal buoyancy, stability and seaworthy conditions of the vessel, and well as the state of the bottom, rudder and screw propeller, the ship was considered fit to proceed on its voyage.

The motor vessel “GOLDEN RAIN” grounded at the anchorage of YANGPU port at 08:28 on 2nd October，2007, on the position of  19°06.20′N/109°06.20′E due to dragging anchor. At that time , the vessel was struggling with the No 15 tropical storm ‘LEKIMA” . With the help of salvage vessels “NANHAI JIU 111” and “NANHAI JIU 131”,  it proceeded to sail at 11:10 on 5th　October, 2007.  The grounding time was 75 hours, and the accident did not cause severe damage to the vessel .

Location: Near DanGan Island in Estuary of Pearl River in Guangdong province, China
SummaryOfEvents: At 0730 2nd, Oct. 2007, DEYUE was towing a for-dismantlement vessel from Guangdong to Shanghai, China, due to heavy sea and rain, the for-dismantlement vessel break into two parts near DanGan Island, one of which sank near the site.

SOLASStatus: F/B LEONE 1CI 0013: Unknown/unspecified, HUAI LAI HE: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: On September 25th 2007 a collision occurred between the container ship HUAI LAI HE and Fishing vessel LEONE. Due to the incident the fishing boat sustained serious damage and partial flooding, resulting in a crew member being washed overboard. The LEONE was subsequently towed to a repair yard in Choggia.  The HUAI LAIE HE did not report any damage. The collision occured between the bow's portside of the container ship and the portside of the fishing vessel. On October 4th the body of  the missing cew member was found at about 15NM from Pila di Porto Tolle.

Location: Off the coast of Wakayama Prefecture, Japan
SummaryOfEvents: At 22.50 hours LT on 24th September 2007 the General cargo ship SILVER ARROW (registered Belize, 3552 gt, built 1980), experienced engine trouble and became unnavigable off the coast of Wakayama Prefecture, Japan. The vessel was towed to safety by tug.

On 24th September 2007  the vessel was en route from Kattegat to the Netherlands, via Kiel. At 16.15 hours LT the vessel grounded because of poor navigation and lack of proper look out.
Two ballast tanks were damaged as a result, but no pollution of the environment occurred.
The vessel was detained by the Danish Martime Authority, and after being refloated she was taken to the repair yard in Fredericia.

On 24th September 2007, the passenger ferry Clansman was on its normal, first early morning schedule.    A short time after leaving port, at 07.40 hours LT, the bridge fire alarm panel sounded indicating that the port main engine oil mist detector had activated.  The chief engineer was able to confirm with the master, who was on the bridge, that there was no fire.  The master informed the passengers of the mechanical situation.  In the meantime the chief engineer confirmed that the port main engine crankcase explosion doors had lifted which had caused the oil mist detector to activate. The port engine was immediately shut down by the chief engineer from the engine control room. The engine was subsequently declutched from the gearbox.

Investigations later identified that No 6 cylinder liner and piston were badly scuffed.  This allowed the cylinder compression gases to pass into the crankcase causing the overpressure which lifted the crankcase explosion doors.  The engine manufacturers found that the oil cooling to the underside of the piston was interrupted by the oil nozzle deflector plate being disturbed.  This caused the oil to flow down the con rod instead of to the underside of the piston.  The piston expanded causing partial seizure.  This resulted in piston and liner scoring, which allowed the compression gases to pass by the piston, pressurising the crankcase.  

The other piston cooling arrangements were checked and were found to be satisfactory.

Location: 25 miles off the East Yorkshire Coast, UK
SummaryOfEvents:
On 29 September 2007, three seamen on board the ERRV Viking Islay lost their lives as a consequence of entering an enclosed space. The ERRV Viking Islay was working in the North Sea conducting rig with the intention of securing a rattling anchor chain within the chain locker. One of the seamen entered the chain locker and collapsed. It is probable that the other seaman, realising that help was urgently required, raised the alarm with the duty watch keeping rating on the bridge before he, too, entered the chain locker in an attempt to help his companion. He also collapsed. 
During the consequent rescue efforts, the first rescuer found he was unable to enter the chain locker wearing a BA, and therefore donned an EEBD.  He entered the space, but at some point the hood of the EEBD was removed, or became dislodged and this rating also collapsed.

All three seamen died as a result of an oxygen deficient atmosphere within the chain locker.

During the voyage one crew member noticed a bad smell in the accomodation, and at the same time a CO2 release alarm suddenly sounded. An investigation by the crew discovered that the thermostat of the heater in the CO2 room did not switch off automatically, increasing the temperature in the CO2 room. This caused some bottles to leak, filling the CO2 room with CO2 gas. Through the natural ventilation CO2 escaped to outside. There it was sucked in to the accomodation area. CO2 gas applied on this vessel was provided with some citronella smell.
On 20th September 2007 the fishing vessel was at sea off Mauritania when a crew member caught his hand in the fish factory machine and sustained serious injuries.

On 17/09/2007 at 04.10 UTC  a ro-ro cargo ship called Gladis suffered a machinery damage that put in danger the efficiency of the ship. Due to the damage to the main engine the m/v was towed to the  Messina's anchorage.

On 17 September 2007 at around 02:20 hours the general cargo ship Katrine Krog, sailing under Danish flag was en route from Saint-Nazaire /France to Denmark. During the passage through the Kiel Canal the pilot was scheduled to change at Rusterbergen station. A pilot ladder was deployed, on which the step third to last was attached only to one side.  

Freeboard of Katrine Krog was approximately 3 m and the pilot ladder had been deployed to approximately 1 m above waterline.

The German pilot pointed out the loose step to the crew of Katrine Krog. When there was no response, he decided to leave out the damaged step by directly stepping onto spreader above. As soon as he stood there with both feet, the rope of the pilot ladder tore off on both sides above the top step. Thereupon the pilot fell down with the torn odd pilot ladder onto the pilot launch, suffering injuries. He managed to embark without  a pilot ladder and to pilot the ship to “Alte Schleuse” locks in Kiel-Holtenau. Katrine Krog continued her voyage after a stopover at the locks.

As a result of his injured, the pilot was unable to work for three days. Nobody else was injured. No damage to property occurred and no environmentally harmful substances were released.

At 13.13 hours LT on the 16th September 2007, an explosion like incident occurred in the switching control room onboard the Edda Fram, whereby a pressure wave was released into the room causing extensive material damage. Amongst other things, the wave of pressure forced open the doors (A60) that lead in and out of the room. One of the doors came into contact with a diesel pipeline resulting in diesel leakage. A manual warning system was activated when the doors were opened by the pressure wave. There was no indication that a fire had occurred in the room.

A crewmember entered the room immediately after the explosion. He was equipped with a flashlight and estimated visibility to be approximately 2 metres. The smoke in the room was perceived to be grey. The crewmembers did not register if the smoke had a particular smell as the diesel leakage emitted a strong diesel odour. The crewmember that entered the room did not proceed very far into the room before returning out again. It was decided to attend to sealing the diesel leakage.

The causal factor of the explosion was identified to be the overheating and subsequent meltdown of an electrical capacitor. This meltdown generated a flammable gas developed from the insulation material in the capacitor. The gas was probably ignited either by the heat from the capacitor or from an electrical spark from one of the electrical breakers.

Corrective measures have been implemented (additional cooling, ventilation, gas detector).

ShipsInvolved: HANJIN GOTHENBURG (IMO 9235103), CHANG TONG (IMO 7709320), HANJIN GOTHENBURG (IMO 9235103)

No one injured or died.

On 14th September 2007 a crew member on board the tug DMS WORLD was electrocuted while repairing a searchlight. The exact cause has not beeen established, but the most probable cause is that electrocution was caused by 24 V system. The 220 V system was found swithed off. The victim had been in a healthy condition.

InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents:
On September 14th, 2007 at 06.10 hours LT, the MV SUNNY DAY – RO/RO CARGO VESSEL – left the Turkish port of Trabzon bound for the Russian port of Sochi, which lies due North approx. 158 N/M. The vessel was laden with 28 units of LONG TRUCKS/TRAILERS (total weight est.1120 MT: out of which there were 27 empty trailers+1 loaded). The Pilot-Capt Mehmet Kulak guided the vessel out of the port and disembarked at approximately 06:40 hours LT. The weather conditions, as per Turkish Gov.METEO report for Sept 14 2007 @ 06:30 LT, stated that: winds W-NW 4-6 ,SEA 1.5 to 2.5 M , Visibility-GOOD. There were no restrictions imposed due to the weather conditions or any other conditions.
During the first six (6) hours the vessel's speed was calculated to be approx. 6.6 KTS. The course was plotted as 359 degrees, but was adjusted due to pitching/pounding to a more favorable course, but by that time the weather conditions had worsened.
At about 12:10 LT the vessel suddenly listed 5-6 degrees to Starboard and then shortly after that listed 2 degree to Port side, and remained listed like that. At approx. 12:25 LT Chief Officer Mr. Husnu Erhan(Turkish National), reported from the main garage deck that sea water was flooding into the garage area. Water was entering through the stern ramp on the Port side and there was already approximately 30-35 cm of water inside the main garage deck. Pump out orders were given but more water was coming in. By this time the vessel list had increased to 5-6 degrees to Port side and was getting worse.
At approx. 12:40 LT the Chief Officer reported the situation to the Turkish Marine Radio Station-TURK RADIO . He also spoke with company DPA Mr.Serdar Erden at the Operator's office. (Transcript of the radio call is available from TURK RADIO ). A MAY-DAY distress call was placed, but by then the vessel had listed further to about 20 degrees. Some of the trucks/trailers on the upper open deck went over the side( 3 units went over the port side ).
At about 12:42 LT the Master called the engine room and ordered all crew to abandon their positions from the machinery spaces. Shortly afterwards the remaining crew and 11 truck drivers were ordered to muster station on the boat deck. Attempts to deploy the two life boats both failed. The
Starboard side life raft was then deployed . The Port side life raft was also deployed but remained connected to the vessel and eventually sank with the vessel. At about 13:10 LT the vessel list increased to aprox. 35 degree and at that time the Master gave verbal orders to abandon the vessel. At 13:20 LT all the crew had abandoned vessel by jumping into the water.
At about 14:00 LT the vessel sank, with the stern going down first .
Rescue efforts were launched and the tanker BATOVA and Turkish tanker TUGCE-T arrived on the scene and rescued most of the crew members and truck drivers. The remainder o the crew was rescued by Turkish Coast Guard chopper. All the crew and truck drivers were safely rescued.
Up until the time of this report, there have been no reports of pollution in the area where the vessel sank.
