On September 10th, 2007 the bulk carrier M/V Voyager II arrived in ballast at the Houston Fairway Anchorage, Galvestone, USA, and was due to load a cargo of Pet Coke on September 17th, 2007 in Houston, USA.
At approximately 18.00 hours LT, on September 12th, 2007 the Master came on the bridge due to the increasing bad weather of Tropical Storm / Hurricane Humberto, joining the OOW and AB, and ordered the Chief Engineer to put the main engines on standby.
At 22.00 hours LT, a security call was received over the VHF from the M/V Naesborg stating that due to the strong winds they were dragging their anchor and were without their main engines. At 22.55 hours LT the Master noticed that the M/V Naesborg called once again on the VHF and reported that they had no control over their vessel. The Master of the M/V Voyager II began to heaving in their port anchor and to maneuver the vessel to avoid coming into full contact with the drifting M/V Naesborg.
At 23.20 hours LT the M/V Naesborg came into contact with the portside of the Voyager II causing damage to both vessels. It later also made contact with a chemical tanker, the MT Valerie, who was also anchored nearby.

On 11th September 2007 the cargo ferry PRIDE OF TELMARK was approaching Hirtshals Harbour when she made contact below the waterline with the foundation of the western pier at the entrance to the harbour. The contact caused three penetrations in the hull below the waterline, which subsequently led to a number of compartments being filled with water.

On 15 September 2007 a Danish containership got problems with its engines. The engines were stopped, and the extent of the damage was so severe that it was necessary to tow the ship from the position. 

The ship was towed to a harbour to be repaired

ON 9TH SEPTEMBER 2007 AT 18.18 HOURS LT, AFTER VESSEL SAILED FROM FALMOUTH, FOUND BALLAST WATER IN No. 1 DB TANK DECREASING. AFTER ARRIVAL NARVIK ANCHORAGE, PUMPED OUT No. 1 DB TANK AND DISCOVERED DAMAGE TO THE SHELL PLATING AND LEAKING.

On September 9th 2007 at approximately 11.12 hours LT the Liberian flag container vessel NORTHERN HAPPINESS was en route to Algeciras, Spain, when she ran aground whilst departing the Bissa Habour. The Master of the NORTHERN HAPPINESS  maneouvered the vessel to clear the port corner in a series of 'slow astern' and 'slow ahead' vessel adjustments. Whilst doing this, the vessel touchec bottom and remained grounded until assistance arrived from crew members of the Stadt Hannover. Both anchors were let go.
NORTHERN HAPPINESS remained fit to proceed without any significant hull damage or injury. Flag State investigation was conducted by obtaining the flag state report and follow-up communications for clarifications after review, as necessary.
SEE ATTACHED REPORT OF INCIDENT ISSUED BY VESSELS MASTER.

At 09.03 hours LT on 8 September 2007 the dredger was on passage to the dumping/spoil grounds in the River Mersey, when she grounded an hour before high water and in an area of changing depths. The sea bed was sandy and the incident occurred in sheltered waters. The dredger pumped out about 1000 cu m of cargo and refloated and returned to her operations. There was no apparent damage.

On September 7th 2007 the engineer officer on watch aboard the tanker SKY STAR discovered flames on the suction side of the turbocharger of the main engine. The engineer stopped the main engine, sounded the general alarm and began to extinguish the fire. The chief engineer stopped ventilators and the separator and began to extinguish the fire, together with the other crew members. The engine room crew began to asses the damages. The turbocharger of the main engine was completely burnt and choked. Damages of greater scale were not discovered. The engine room having been cleaned, the main engine was started. In order to supply the main engine with air there were 2 electric blowers working on the emergency regime. The main engine was stopped after 1 hour 10 minutes in operation, for the supply of air was insufficient. 
The master ordered a tug from Tallinn.

Location: Off port waters of New Mangalore Port
SummaryOfEvents: At 12.00 hours on 6th September 2007 the m/v CHANG LE MEN sailed from New Manglore with a cargo of ironore fines in all holds. After clearing the port channel at about 13.00 hours LT the vessel developed a 3 degree list to starboard side. The master notified the port and asked for assistance and re-berthing. The listing increased to 16.8 degrees and efforts were made to pump out the water in the hold, but with no success as the cargo mixed with the water had shifted to the starboard side. At that point the situation had become dangerous to the crew members, and at 14.25 hours the Master grounded the vessel near the beach area of the port to avoid capsizing. With the assistance of salvors and lightening of cargo the vessel was re-floated on 13th September 2007. the vessel was then anchored at the old new Manglore port. There were no casualties and no environmental damage.

Location: Between Qua Iboe and US Gulf/Loop
SummaryOfEvents:
The ship Pacific Lagoon was on a passage coming from Qua Iboe and bound for the US Gulf/Loop.

On 4 September 2007, it was planned to start the removal of mud in ballast tank 4 starboard. Therefore, a riding squad was on board, additional to the crew contingent, existing out of 4 Indonesians.

After completion of entry checks, green light was given to enter the ballast tank. The foreman of the riding squad entered the tank first, followed by two other members. Soon afterwards, the foreman was found fallen down, unconscious but breathing with a large head wound and bleeding from his right ear and nose.

The alarm was raised and the Chief Officer entered the tank to give first aid. Later in the ship’s hospital, the condition of the victim worsened until he passed away.

The ship continued her voyage towards Martinique from where the body of the deceased was repatriated.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
The SICHEM AMETHYST is a chemical tanker which was en-route from Livorno to Gibraltar for bunkers, then to Dakar in Senegal for discharge. On the 3rd September 2007 around midnight the vessel reported technical difficulties with the on  board Auxiliary engines which  resulted in the vessel suffering loss of power & subsequently propulsion. After trying to carry out on board repairs with help from office & makers the vessel was unable to restore main power using the generators. The SICHEM AMETHYST was finally towed & safely berthed in the port of Cartagena on 5th September 2007 where she underwent repairs under Class supervision. Vessel left Cartagena on completion of repairs on the 10th September 07 & safely arrived Gibraltar under her own power on 11th September 07 for bunkering. Thence the vessel is trading normally & all the AEs are functioning satisfactorily & all parameters are within normal limits.
The quality of the fuel was suspected, and the final analysis (spectrometry) results are expected to stablish the root cause.

On August 31st 2007 at about 21.34 hours LT, the container ship "CMA CGM TEMA" was leaving the port of Jiangyin , Fujian in China, when she collided with M/V HAI SHENG 68, who was entering the harbour. At 1400 hours LT on 30th August 2007 at  Lat.  06-17.2N  Long 103-44 5E the boatswain of the bulk carrier NEW GUARDIAN heard a loud noise and saw there was a small ship capsizing alongside the vessel's startboard hull.  He reported to the bridge and master manoeuvred the vessel to the site for search and rescue.  It was reported that seven crew menbers had been rescued by another small fishing boat, but that two crew members were trapped in the engine room of the capsized boat.

Master tried to upright and secure the capsized boat from sinking by ship's crane,  but failed.  Two survivors were accepted by the vessel and the telephone number of the owner of capsized boat was given to master. The vessel kept searching under the order of Singapore SAR until the following night, but nothing was found.  Finally, Singapore Sar advised New Guardian to "stand down" the mission. On 16th August 2007 a third engineer was serving onboard the container ship NEDLLOYD HUDSON, and was engaged in cleaning the turbo charger of the main engine, which he had previously done on a number of occasions.  The procedure involved adding crushed fruit nut shells to a funnel on the turbo charger inlet.  When the funnel was at the required level, compressed air at between 6-8 bars was opened onto the funnel, which then discharged the shells into the turbo charger through a valve arrangement.  The abrasion effect of the shells cleans the turbo charger.  This operation is undertaken every 24- 48 hours.

On this occasion, when the compressed air was admitted to the system the sealing olive on the copper discharge pipe to the turbo charger failed and the shells were ejected under pressure onto the arms and back of the third engineer.  This caused extensive and severe abrasion to his forearms which required him to be hospitalised.

Investigations found that the copper discharge pipe was largely unsupported throughout its length and this caused the connection sealing olive to fail through fatigue.  It was further found that the third engineer had his coverall sleeves rolled up and was therefore unprotected.  Where his back was protected by his coveralls he suffered minimal damage.

The pipe work has since been correctly supported and clipped and the requirement for coverall sleeves to be fully rolled down re-iterated by the ship¿s and management company¿s safety committees.

Location: en route from Mumbai to Chennai, India
SummaryOfEvents:
On 10th August 2007 the oil tanker M.T. HOMI BHABHA set out from Mumbai to Chennai, India, with a cargo of 3667 tons of crude oil. On 15th  August the bridge received a message from the Engine room that the "high water level" alarm had been activated in the pump room. By 14.00 hours the pump room was flooded with up to 4.5 metres of water. Efforts to evacuate the water were unsuccessful and the water level continued to rise. The situation was stabilised by 18.00 hours and the vessel proceeded on her voyage to Chennai, arriving on 17th August at 10.00 hours LT.
A repair team with divers located the sea valves in the bilge area and took action to close them at Chennai. Once this had been done the water was pumped out and the vessel berthed for discharge of cargo. No loss of life or incident of oil pollution was reported.

Location: at anchor off Dampier, Western Australia
SummaryOfEvents:
On 14 August 2007, the Antigua and Barbuda registered general cargo ship BBC Islander anchored off Dampier, Western Australia. One of the tasks the crew was to complete while the ship was at anchor was the removal of steel brackets that had been welded to the hatch covers.

In the process of removing the brackets with oxy-acetylene cutting equipment, a hole was inadvertently cut in the aft cargo hold hatch cover. As a result, sparks and molten metal fell into the cargo hold and onto the pallets of cargo stowed below.  

At about 13.40 hours LT, smoke was noticed coming from the aft cargo hold. The general alarm was sounded and the master decided to use the ship’s fixed fire extinguishing system to flood the cargo hold with carbon dioxide.

The harbour master was notified and he arranged for the ship to be brought alongside the wharf.

By 13.12 hours on 16 August, BBC Islander was all fast alongside the wharf and the local fire- fighting authorities took control of the response. Initially, they tried flooding the cargo hold with more carbon dioxide. They then attempted to remove the cargo in order to reach the seat of the fire and extinguish it with the use of fire hoses. Eventually, the hold was filled with high expansion foam. However, none of these actions extinguished the fire.

On 18th August, the fire was finally extinguished when an offshore supply vessel’s fire monitor was used to flood BBC Islander’s aft cargo hold with about 700 tonnes of seawater.

On 13th August 2007 the passenger liner QUEEN ELIZABETH 2 was en route to Lisbon when, at 00.05 hours LT one of nine engines was started.
The engine parameters were all normal until 01.05 hours LT, at which time the oil mist detector on the engine indicated a fault.  As a precaution the engine was being prepared to be stopped when the motorman saw what he believed to be smoke in the vicinity of the engine.  The engine emergency stop was operated, the hi-fog system was released and propeller pitch limited to 70%.  The smoke detection system of the fire alarm panel sounded and the engineers alarm was activated.  The vessel speed was reduced to slow ahead.
At 01.20 hours LT, the captain and command team arrived on the bridge and the crew went to alert stations. At 01.25 hours LT the situation was reported as being under control and the engine room was ventilated to remove the apparent smoke.  All areas were confirmed normal at 01.40 hours LT.

Subsequent investigations found that No 8 cylinder of the affected engine had suffered liner scoring which resulted in the compressed fuel/air mixture passing into the engine sump.  The sump became pressurised which then cased the crankcase explosion doors to open, discharging oil vapour into the engine room.  There was no fire.

The engine manufacturer's representative was onboard but the exact cause of the scoring is undetermined.  The cylinder liner, piston rings and piston have been replaced and the engine successfully commissioned.

On 8th August 2007 THE VESSEL WAS ON PASSAGE FROM TUTICORIN, INDIA TO PORT DAMPIER, WESTERN AUSTRALIA. SHE WAS IN BALLAST DURING THE PASSAGE AND CLEANING THE HOLDS WAS IN PROGRESS, IN PREPARATION FOR A CARGO OF SALT.  BALLAST EXCHANGE WAS ALSO BEING CONDUCTED.
THE BRIDGE LOG BOOK SHOWS THE VESSEL WAS STEERING A COURSE OF 128 DEGREES. ON THE DAY OF THE INCIDENT THE WIND HAD BACKED FROM SOUTH WEST TO SOUTH WHILE STILL MAINTAINING FORCE 5. THE VESSEL HAD BEEEN ROLLING MODERATELY ALL DAY IN THE ROUGH SEAS AND SWELL. THERE HAD BEEN PASSING SHOWERS SINCE NOON.
THE MASTER HAD BEEN ABOARD SINCE SEPTEMBER 2005. THE DECEASED JOINED IN JULY 2006. HIS DUTY  WATCH WAS THE 12 TO 4 AND HE HAD BEEN WORKING THIS ROUTINE FOR ALL OF JULY AND AUGUST UP TO THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT. THERE WAS SOME OVERTIME WORKED IN JULY AND AUGUST BUT IT WAS NOT EXCESSIVE.
THE HOLDS WERE BEING CLEANED WITH MURIATIC ACID (HYDROCHLORIC). SINCE DEPATURE ON 06TH  AUGUST HOLD CLEANING HAD STARTED FROM HOLD ONE, THEN ON TO HOLD TWO, WITH THE COMPLETION OF HOLD TWO ON 08TH AUGUST 2007. THE TWO ABs RICARDO CRONOLOGIA AND JOB DEOLOPEZ (DECEASED) WENT TO HOLD THREE. THE HOSE WAS SET UP IN THE HOLD AND THE PUMP WAS BEING OPERATED BY THE BOSUN (RENATO BELLEZA). THEY STARTED IN THE PORT AFT CORNER ON DECK AND WERE WORKING THEIR WAY FORWARD UP THE PORT SIDE WHEN THE BOSUN CALLED ON THE PORTABLE VHF TO STOP WORK FOR THE DAY AT APPROXIMATELY 16.45 HOURS LT.
RICARDO WENT UP THE AUSTRALIAN LADDER, AT THE AFTER END OF THE HOLD. JOB WENT UP THE VERTICAL LADDER AT THE FORWARD END OF THE HOLD.
RICARDO WAS NEAR THE BODY HATCH ACCESS WHEN HE HEARD THE NOISE OF A BODY FALLING ONTO THE TANK TOPS. HE CALLED FOR HELP ON HIS RADIO AND WENT ON DECK TO SEEK MORE HELP. HE THEN WENT TO THE MESS ROOM SUFFERING FROM SHOCK.

THE MASTER HEARD THE CALL AND WENT TO THE BRIDGE. HE SENT THE CHIEF OFFICER, WHO WAS ON WATCH, TO THE SCENE. OTHERS AROUND THE SHIP ALSO HEARD THE CALL ON THEIR RADIOS AND CONVERGED ON THE SCENE.
WHILE THE MASTER WAS CONTACTING THE OWNERS AND RCC SRI LANKA, SINGAPORE AND AUTRALIA, THE CREW CHECKED THE BODY. THEY REMOVED THE BODY FROM THE HOLD USING A NET AND ROPES. ON DECK THE CLOTHES WERE REMOVED, THE BODY CLEANED AND WRAPPED IN A BLANKET AND THEN PLASTIC. A PLYWOOD BOX WAS CONSTRUCTED AND THE BODY PLACED INSIDE. THE FREEZER WAS CLEANED OUT AND THE BODY PLACED INSIDE UNTIL AUSTRALIA.
1/AE GILLANA, ALSO ON BOARD SINCE JULY 2006 TOOK PHOTOS OF THE SCENE AND PRIOR TO PLACING IN THE FREEZER. THESE ARE INCLUDED WITH THE PHOTOS TAKEN BY ME WHEN IN PORT.

1.1          At 22.35 LT on 28th July 2007, during a berthing operation at the port of St Helier in Jersey, Channel Islands, the High Speed Craft HD1 carrying passengers and vehicles contacted the moored High Speed Craft CONDOR EXPRESS whilst attempting to berth at the West Berth of the Elizabeth Harbour.  
1.2.	At the time of the accident the CONDOR EXPRESS was completing loading at the East berth of Elizabeth Harbour.
1.3.	Originally it had been planned for HD1 to berth on the East berth. The East berth is also the preferred operating berth for other HSC operating into the port as the Link span is self supporting and permits simultaneous load/discharge or 2 door load on the 74 & 86m Incat vessels. A delay in the loading operation and departure of CONDOR EXPRESS necessitated the change of berthing plan and alternative arrangements.
1.4.	The decision to enter port and berth on the less suitable West berth was made by the master in conjunction with the port control. The choice was made in preference to waiting outside the harbour, in reaction to worsening weather conditions. The HD1 had a Jersey Pilot on board.
1.5.	Both vessels were registered in the Bahamas.
1.6.	There were no reported injuries to passengers or crew of either vessel.  
1.7.	HD1 suffered penetration of the hull on the port side, affecting three longitudinal compartments with distortion of shell plating and structure in a further two compartments.  The damage was found to be about 0.7m above the waterline at the time. Apart from insignificant splash accumulations in the holed compartments of HD1 there was no influx of water to the damaged hull.
1.8.	CONDOR EXPRESS sustained superficial damage to the starboard bow that, after inspection was deemed not to affect the seaworthiness of the vessel and there was no influx of water.
1.9.	Both vessels were fitted with Voyage Data Recorders and the data from both has been utilised during the investigations, as was Jersey Harbour CCTV recordings of the incident.
1.10.	A number of action points resulting from the incident have already been implemented and they are detailed together with further recommendations within this report.

On 28 July 2007, Lady Candida was cruising 3 miles off the South coast of Corsia. On Board were a crew of 6 and 11 passengers, 4 of whom were young children. At about 16:30, hours a fire was detected in the yacht’s laundry. Despite efforts to extinguish the fire using portable extinguishers, it quickly spread out of control and the passengers and two of the crew were evacuated to the shore in the ship’s open tender. At 16:40 hours the captain broadcast a Mayday and soon afterwards he and the remaining crew abandoned the ship into a liferarft.  They were soon recovered by a nearby ship. The fire was later extinguished by shore-based rescue ships, but Lady Candida sank when being towed clear of the Bonifacio nature reserve. There were no casualties.

On 27th July 2007, at 12.45 LT, the MV Woo Chang collided with MV Zhe Daiyu 04224
which was anchoring, and caused damage to the middle part of the fishing boat.

SOLASStatus: ALPHA ACTION: SOLAS, WAN HAI 307: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
The bulk carrier ALPHA ACTION  (registered Greece, 77,211 gt, built 1994), with 23 crew (Filipino: 13, Greek: 10), sailed in ballast condition from the port of Nagoya, Japan on July 26th 2007 at 17.00 hours LT.  On July 27th at 01.50 hours LT she collided with the Container ship Wan Hai 307 (registered Singapore, 25836 gt, built 2002), with 21 crew (Chinese: 9, Myanmarese: 7, Indonesian: 3, Taiwanese: 2), about 16 kilometers SW from Iro-saki lighthouse, Shizuoka Prefecture, Japan, LAT: 34° 35' N , LONG: 139° 18' E.
The bow of Alpha Action wedged into the stern of Wan Hai 307, and both vessels were adrift eastward until salvage ships separated them and they were towed to the port of Yokohama some 3 days later.
ALPHA ACTION sustained damage to her fore peak tank and water ingress, while Wan Hai 307 sustained significant damage to the hull and some containers, and became unnavigable when the engine compartment flooded.
Some oil had leaked from Wan Hai 307 causing a slick. None of the crew on board the vessels was hurt.
On August 6th 2007 the M/V "ALPHA ACTION" sailed by her own means to the yard of Zhousan, China, for repairs

Location: From Hereke, Turkey, towards Constanta, Romania
SummaryOfEvents:
The MV Multi Trader under Cambodian flag was sailing from Hereke Harbour, Turkey to Constanta, Romania, with a quantity of 1002.133 kg of gypsum spray plaster packet in 976 plaster packet in 976 plastic bags.
On 25 July 2007, the ship came out of Bosporus Strait and headed towards Constanta.
The next day, 26 July 2007 the weather conditions were really bad and around 04:00 hours the ship listed to the portside and the main deck was continuously flooded with sea water.
Same day, all measure taken in order to bring her to the normal condition failed and she slowly continue to list more and more to the portside.
At 19:00 hours Multi Trader’s captain contacted Mangalia’s Harbour’s Master Office and informed that the ship is taking water heavily in the ballast tanks and ask for help. From 19:30 hours the ship went offline.
Mangalia’s Harbour’s Master Office sent the Frontier Police to the scene. Around 21:25 hours, two Frontier Police motorboats arrived at the scene and rescue the crew from the life boats. The crew was unharmed.
Multi Trader sunk entirely at 21:25 hours

ON 26th JULY 2007 AT 12:10 HOURS LT THE AB MR. TARIO DOMINGO WAS CARRYING OUT HIS NORMAL DUTIES WHEN HE COLLAPSED UNCONCIOUS. HE WAS TRANSFERRED BY CREW TO THE SHÌP`S HOSPITAL FOR FIRST AID, & THE VESSEL REQUESTED DOCTOR & AMBULANCE FROM THE TERMINAL & THE AGENT.
AT 12:20 HOURS LT TERMINAL`S NURSE BOARDED THE VESSEL
AT 12:25 HOURS LT DR. J.MENDEZ BOARDED THE VESSEL & CONTINUED THE FIRST AID.
AT 12:07 HOURS LT DR. J.MENDEZ DECLARED THAT TARIO DOMINGO PASSED AWAY. THE RESULT OF THE AUTOPSY  WAS NATURAL CAUSE OF DEATH.

Le 25 juillet 2007 en début de matinée, le fileyeur La Fouine se trouve à 15 milles dans le Nord de Dieppe. Il achève le filage d’une tessure de trémails, dans le sens du courant, à une vitesse de 5 nœuds.

Les conditions météo sont bonnes : vent de Sud ouest 8 à 10 nœuds, mer  2, visibilité 15 milles. C’est le début du jusant et le coefficient de marée est de 35.

A la fin du filage, un matelot, occupé à préparer un filet, est entraîné par-dessus bord.

La victime essaie de nager mais ne peut se maintenir à la surface. Un matelot se jette à l’eau et tente sans succès de secourir son collègue. A la timonerie, le patron manœuvre  rapidement pour remonter à bord de sauveteur et la victime qui, malgré les soins prodigués, ne peut être ranimée.

In the early morning of 24th July 2007, the bulk carrier WHITE MIST was transiting Panama Canal southward for Balboa from Cristobal, with two pilots on board, when it encountered foggy weather. The pilot reduced speed but visibility decreased and at 00.27 hours LT she collided with the dredger MILTIADES. No water ingress was found in any tanks or holds during that time. No injuries WERE incurred by vessel or crew.

On 23rd July 2007 the fishing boat ROSEMARIE was taking her nets on board during a fishing operation.  One hook - used to bring nets in and out - suddenly slipped  through a block in the mast, hitting a crew member who was working on deck. The crew member was taken ashore to be treated but died of his injuries one week later.

On 22nd July 2007 the vessel Crane Arrow, General Cargo Ship, IMO Nr 8308147, Flag Bahamas, Call Sign C6JG6, caught fire at position latitude 01° 06.8S and longitude 048°29.3W in Para state,  North Brazil. The fire started in the engine room around 06.30  hours LT. After the smoke alarm detector had been heard, fire combat teams were formed and tried to enter the engine room without success. The engine room was locked and the automatic fire extinguisher system was activated. After a little more than 24 hours the fire was extinguished.
The auxiliary generator and part of the eletric wire in the engine room were damaged, and the ship was unable to resume its journey. Brazilian Navy opened an Inquiry to investigate the reasons for the accident. The vessl was pronounced unfit to proceed. During the fire combat operations no injury and no pollution (no oil spill ) were observed.

At 06.35 hours LT the general cargo ship BAGDAD was proceeding out of the Shatt al Arab Waterway - seaway of Khorramshahr when the vessel was attacked by three people using automatic rifles. Several bullets hit the superstructure of the vessel, but the gunmen departed shortly afterwards, with no injuries to crew members and no pollution. The Iranian CG and PFSO advised at time of incident.
During sailing manoeuvre heavy wind gives vessel a big list. 7 passengers flushed over board, but rescue by passing catamaran.

On July 17th 2007 at about 0916Hrs local time, MV ANNA RICKMERS registered LIBERIA carrying with coal and steel pipes(total 25576.464MT) who was on her way from Tianjin for Zhangjiagang in dense fog with visibility less than 50 meters, collided with MV “SHUILUZHANG 3”at position 37°35.20′N 122°38.60′E. It caused MV ANNA RICKMERS damaged with her starboard bow and MV SHUILUZHANG 3 damaged with her head, nobody was injured.

AT ABOUT 09.50 HOURS LT, THE DUTY OFFICER OF THE SAFETY SQUAD NOTICED SMOKE COMING OUT FROM NO. 2C TANK AND IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED THE MASTER VIA VHF. THE MASTER RAN TO THE SCENE TOGETHER WITH OTHER SHORE LABOURERS, CREW AND THE SUPERINTENDENT. THEY TRIED TO ENTER THE TANK BUT IT WAS NOT POSSIBLE DUE TO HEAT AND SMOKE -  FIRE FIGHTING MEANS WERE EMPLOYED TO PUT OUT THE FIRE AND REDUCE THE HEAT.
SOON AFTERWARDS THE FIRE BRIGADE ARRIVED, BUT ALTHOUGH THE FIRE WAS SMALL THE HEAT PREVENTED THE RESCUE TEAM FROM ENTERING THE TANKS. WHEN THEY WERE FINALLY ABLE TO ENTER THEY FOUND THAT THE TWO SHORE WORKERS WERE DEAD.
THE COURT APPOINTED TWO EXPERTS TO INVESTIGATE THE CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT TOGETHER WITH UNIONS AND OTHER MARINE EXPERTS.  AS OF THIS DATE THE INVESTIGATION HAS NOT BEEN COMPLETED.

At 02.50 local time on July 16 2007 MAIN ORE, a Panama bulk ore vessel, broke her berth lines when discharging. She was set adrift, and at 03.45h local time MAIN ORE became stranded on a rock named WAIMATI to the south-east side of the berth, at position 30°39′.49N/122°26′.00E. The accident resulted in damage to, and a partial break of the bottom of the ship.

Le chalutier pêche arrière Cavalier des Vagues II quitte le port de Boulogne-sur-Mer en début d’après-midi le 15 juillet 2007 pour se rendre sur son lieu de pêche.
Les conditions météorologiques sont bonnes. Le lendemain, en action de pêche, le patron remonte son chalut. Il constate que ce dernier est anormalement lourd.
En tentant de larguer le cul du chalut, alors qu’il est suspendu au portique, il vient sur tribord. Le navire prend une gîte importante et chavire.
Les trois marins se retrouvent à l’eau et parviennent, non sans difficulté pour le patron, à s’agripper à la quille. L’alerte ne peut être donnée. L’épave et les trois naufragés vont dériver pendant trois heures environ.
L’équipage du Cavalier des Vagues II est récupéré sain et sauf par le navire de pêche Noemie après que celui-ci ait heurté l’épave. Durant les manoeuvres d’approche pour embarquer les naufragés, le Noemie engage son hélice dans le chalut du navire chaviré. Ne pouvant manoeuvrer, il est alors pris en remorque par un autre navire de pêche.
Le Cavalier des Vagues II finit par sombrer.

Last 15 july 2007 the Ro-Ro cargo ship Transmodal, Port of registry Buenos Aires (Argentina), IMO nr 8301785, Call sign LQBJ, in navigation coming from Rio de Janeiro Harbor with destiny to Buenos Aires' Harbor caught fire at position latitude 6º45,6S and longitude 047º47,8W around 3.00 PM.
The main machine was stopped and the fire bomb was put in operation and sounded the alarm of  fire. Soon after it, a blackout occurred, leaving  the ship without electric power. In front of the situation it proceded the engine room abandonment, and it was activated CO2's fixed system. The ship sent Distress' Messages for equipment INMARSART, BLU and VHF message MAYDAY, being the same answered by the ship QUINN J, flag of Islands Cayman. 
Having in mind the fire spreading in the stern, by portside, nearby the lifeboats and exhausted all the possible means, the Commander ordered to abandon the ship.  Around the 6.15 PM of the same day all hands were rescued by the ship QUINN J. 
All rescued crew  presented good shape of health,  nobody was injured. 
The fire, considered of large proportions, burnt all the top to the engine room and the bridge. The ship was unable to prosecute travel with its own propulsion,  no kind of pollution to the marine environment was observed.

InitialEvent: accident due to a failure during mooring operations
SummaryOfEvents: During the final phase of mooring by dock no. 4 of OLBIA's port, while waiting to embark on M/v MOBY TOMMY, two passengers had been suddenly hit by a piece of the mooring rope. The first person was promptly rescued and rushed to Olbia civilian hospital while the second one didn't suffered any injuries and decided to embark on the ship.
Consequences1: Ship remains fit to proceed,Serious injuries

Location: Off Amherst Island, Lake Ontario, ontario
SummaryOfEvents: On 13 July 2007 at approximately 16:00 hours eastern daylight time, a fire broke out near the auxiliary propulsion engine of the sail training ship Fair Jeanne off Amherst Island near Kingston, Ontario. After initial fire fighting attempts, the 20 sea cadets on board, along with several crew members and two naval personnel, were evacuated. Volunteer fire fighters extinguished the fire. The ship was towed to Kingston to assess the damage. One cadet received minor injuries.

THE BULK CARRIER "LUMINOUS HALO" WAS AT ANCHORAGE AT 22.20 HOURS LT ON 12th JULY, 2007, WHEN PARADIP PORT CONTROL CALLED UP AND INSTRUCTED CREW TO HEAVE UP ANCHOR FOR ALONGSIDE AS THE PILOT WOULD COME ON BOARD AT 23.30 HOURS LT. 
BY 22.45 HOURS LT  THE ANCHOR WAS AWEIGH AND THE VESSEL LEFT THE ANCHORAGE AREA.  THE WEATHER AT THAT TIME WAS WIND WSW TO SW, BF SCALE 5 AND HEIGHT OF SWELL WAS 3.0 METERS. 
AT 23.00 HOURS LT THE BOSUN, 2 A/B AND 2 O/S PREPARED STARBOARD SIDE PILOT LADDER COMBINATION AND BEGAN SETTING MANROPES/GUIDE AT EACH STANCHEON WHILE THE LADDER WAS STILL AT DECK LEVEL.  
SUDDENLY AT 23.05 HOURS LT  THE WIRE ROPE OF PILOT ASSIST LADDER PARTED/ CUT OFF AND CAUSED BOSUN TO FALL OVERBOARD.
ALL PARTIES WERE INFORMED OF MAN OVERBOARD, AND IMMEDIATE ASSISTANCE WAS REQUESTED FROM PARADIP PORT CONTROL. 
THEY SENT PILOT BOAT AND ASSISTED THE SEARCH AND RESCUE OPERATION AND INFORMED COASTGUARD IMMEDIATELY. INFORMED ALL PARTIES IN JAPAN, FIRST MARINE SERVICES, MARANAW LUZON SHIPPING OFFICE IN MANILA. SEARCH AND RESCUE OPERATION CONTINUED BY M/V LUMINOUS HALO UNTIL 14.35 HOURS LT ON 13th JULY, WHEN CREW WAS INSTRUCED BY PORT CONTROL TO PROCEED TO PILOT STATION FOR BERTHING.  SEARCH AND RESCUE OPERATION RESULTS WERE NEGATIVE.

Location: 107 miles off the Masqat Lighthouse in Oman
SummaryOfEvents:
On 18th June 2007 at 03.36 hours LT the Korean-registered cargo vessel Orchid Sun left the port of Xingang, China for the port of Bandar Imam Khomeini, Iran, with a crew of 23, carrying 42,040MT of wire rod & deformed bar.
At 22.00 hours LT on 9 July, the crew discovered that No.1 cargo hold was flooded with water and she kept navigating in Arabian sea.
She sank in position 23º 52' 06"N-060º 40' 54"E, 107 miles off the Masqat lighthouse in Oman in the direction of 082º at 0822 on 12 July 2007.
- One crew member was dead and twelve crew members went missing.

THE MENTIONED VESSEL LEFT THE PORT OF KIMBE FOR THE PORT OF ZHANGJIAGANG, CHINA WITH ABOUT 8,310 CUBIC SQUARE METERS OF ROUND LOGS ON JUNE 30, 2007, AND ENCOUNTERED A TROPICAL STORM (0704) NEAR THE GUAN IN THE OPEN SEA ON JULY 10, 2007, AND SUNK NEARBY(13925 E/ 1652N) DUE TO THE WATER FILLED INTO CARGO HOLD NO.1, AND LISTED AND CAPSIZED AT 0415LT ON JULY 11, 2007; THERE ARE TOTAL 22 CREWMEMBERS SERVED ON BOARD, AND THREE OF THEM DIED  IN THE CASUALTY (TWO BODY WERE IDENTIFIED), AND SIX OF THEM WERE MISSING, AND THE OTHERS HAD COME BACK TO CHINA THROUGH VARIOUS PATHS AND WERE STAYING FOR REST IN THEIR FAMILY (ONE OF THEM WAS INJURED, AND STAYED IN THE HOSPITAL FOR TREATMENT FOR A LONG TIME, AND LEFT JUST NOW).
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life

SummaryOfEvents: After sailing from Auckland New Zealand, the ship ran into heavy weather which was in excess of that forecast before sailing. The ship suffered damage to fittings and fixtures including loss of the satellite communications dome, various aerials and antennae, and some windows cracked due to the working of the ship in the seaway. The following day, investigation of water leaking into the hull identified two areas where pre-existing corrosion damage had been exacerbated by the storm, and the ship side plating had begun to weep water in the forepeak tank, and through structural ventilation ducts.

THE VEHICLE CARRIER 'GRUS'  ARRIVED SHIN KASADO DOCKYARD ON 26th JUNE 2007 FOR ROUTINE DOCKING AND SURVEYS, AND ENTERED DRYDOCK NO. 5 ON 27th JUNE
ON 10th JULY AT 11.15 HOURS LT AN EXPLOSION OCCURRED IN HER BOTTOM PLATFORM FORWARD OF MAIN ENGINE WHILE  DOCKYARD WORKERS AND SHIP´S ENGINEERS WERE WORKING ON VARIOUS JOBS (INCLUDING HOT WORK) AROUND MAIN ENGINE AND BOILER.
THE DOCKYARD TOOK FULL RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE EXPLOSION (WHICH POSSIBLY OCCURRED DUE TO COMBUSTION OF COLLECTED, SPILLED CLEANING AGENTS).
AS A RESULT, THE SHIP´S 4TH ENGINEER SUFFERED SUPERFICIAL FACIAL BURNS AND RECEIVED FIRST AID AT THE LOCAL HOSPITAL IN TOKUYAMA.
14 DOCKYARD WORKERS WERE ALSO TAKEN TO TOKUYAMA GENERAL HOSPITAL. OUT OF THESE, 3 WORKERS RECEIVED SECOND DEGREE BURNS AND WERE KEPT IN ICU. THE REMAINING WERE DISCHARGED AFTER FIRST AID.
THE SHIP´S CREW / MANAGERS WERE IN NO WAY INVOLVED WITH EITHER THE INCIDENT OR THE SUBSEQUENT INVESTIGATIONS CARRIED OUT BY THE LOCAL POLICE.
THE DOCKYARD ASSUMED FULL RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE INCIDENT.
THE VESSEL LEFT SHIN KASADO ON 18th JULY 2007 AFTER COMPLETION OF ALL PLANNED REPAIRS.

On 10th July 2007 the combined chemical and oil tanker GENKI STAR  (registered Panama, 1930 gt, built 2006) with 14 crew (Japanese: 1, South Korean: 2, Filipino: 11), grounded on shallows in latitude 35 40.318N, longitude 139 57.046E.
Local agents arranged tugs, which refloated the vessel.
Damage to hull was limited to peeling of bottom paint coating.
At 12.40 hours LT on 7th July 2007 the M/V SASANQUA was approximately 1000 miles north-west of the Cape Verde Islands when a fire broke out in the engine room, rendering the ship unfit to proceed.

Location: SABINE PASS OUTER BAR CHANNEL BREAKWATER
SummaryOfEvents:
AT 08:15LT/6th/JUL/2007 SABINE PASS PILOT ON BOARD MY VESSEL AND PROCEED TO PORT BEAUMONT.
AT 09:54 MY VESSEL TOUCHED THE SABINE PASS EAST JETTY. AT 09:55 SLOW ASTERN, AT 10:02 ENGINE STOP, AT 10:13 P/PASSED N0.34 L/B, 10:55 DROPPED ANCHOR, 11:18 FINISHED WITH ENGINE. 11:52 DROP PILOT.
NOW WE FOUND THE N0.4 WBT S`SIDE TANK LEAKING. VESSEL HAVE 2 DEGREES LIST TO PORT SIDE. NOW ANCHORED AT FAIRWAY ANCHORAGE FOR FURTHER INSTRUCTION AND POSITION LAT 29º35N, LONG 093º45W.

El buque TORNADO tenia programado proceder directamente desde el puerto de Abidján a Las Palmas , pero debido a la falta de combustible  fue necesario programar una escala en la rada de Nouadhibou para tomar unas 15 mtons de gas oil, lo cual le proporcionaba  un  mejor margen de seguridad 

			Arribo a la rada de Nouadhibou el día 4 de Mayo de 2007  a las 1500 hrs.  abarloándose a su costado de babor el buque SHELF, maniobrando posteriormente para fondear con su ancla de estribor.  Finalizada la operación de trasiego de combustible levo anclas sobre las 2200 hrs., maniobrando para facilitar el desabarloamiento del buque SHELF, posteriormente procedió a parar maquinas y arranchar las defensas Yokohama que pendían por el costado de babor.

                                 Finalizada la operación  arrumbaron hacia la salida , produciéndose la Colisión con el pesquero NAVIGATOR sobre las 23 06 hrs., como mas adelante se detalla,  el cual se encontraba fondeado. 

                                 El buque TORNADO, con daños estructurales en su bulbo y amurada de proa – estribor  prosiguió su rumbo a Las Palmas, en donde fue detenido por las Autoridades Marítimas (PSC). 

                                 El pesquero NAVIGATOR, se hundió debido a los daños sufridos en su costado .

On 3rd July 2007 the JORDAN EXPRESS  was lowering her port anchor when at approximately 8:35 hours the anchor fell into the sea, resulting in a serious injury to one seaman and slight injury to the Bosun.

On July 1st 2007 the passenger vessel ECSTASY was in open seas when at  07:34 hours LT one of the passengers, MR.DAVID RITCHESON, jumped overboard. The man overboard procedure was immediately activated and at 07.55 hours LT the man was recovered from the sea. At 08.09 hours LT the passenger was pronounced dead by the ship's doctor.

Location: North entrance to channel at Cochin Port, India
SummaryOfEvents: On 17 April 2007 the general cargo ship MARIA S left Tiaiyin, China, en route to Albania  with a cargo of steel rods and trucks. Her jpurney was repeatedly delayed by heavy weather, ingress of water and listing, and a change of crew took place at Singapore. Temporary repairs were carried out at Tuticorn (India), and the vessel anchored off the southern coast to take shelter. When the vessel arrived at Cochin outer anchorage she was denied entry by the port authorities, and was detained by the PSC on 29th June 2007 because of serious deficiencies. The vessel eventually sank on 30th June 2007 at a location north of the entrance to  the channel at Cochin Port. The vessel was in the charge of a Pilot, and there was no loss of life or major case of oil pollution.

On 30th June 2007 the M/V PRINKIPO was inbound to King George V dock in Hull to load a cargo of maize oil. At 03.00 hours the M/V WMS Harlingen was outbound when the two vessels collided. Both vessels were under pilotage at the time. The collision occurred in a position just to the east of the Anson buoy, approximately 0.3 nm north west of the Saltend jetty. The collision appears to have occurred due to a "manoeuvring problem" on board m/v WMS Harlingen. No injuries to personnel were reported and there was no pollution.

THE BULK CARRIER M/V RONGA ARRIVED AT PADANG PORT, INDONESIA ON 31st  MAY 2007 AND ANCHORED OFF ROADS. ON 3 JUNE 2007 SHE BERTHED IN TO LOAD PORLAND CEMENT CARGO IN BULK FOR DISCHARGING AT HAMARIYA PORT, UAE. SHE LOADED 30115MT CARGO AND SAILED ON 7TH JUNE.
ON 29th JUNE 2007 AT 23.55HRS, THE VESSEL WAS SAFELY GROUNDED IN POSITION: LAT 20 45.24N LONG 070º38.33E OFF MULDWARKA PORT, INDIA.  A SECOND EMERGENCY MESSAGE ABOUT GROUNDING OF VESSEL WAS SENT ON DSC AND MF/HF/VHF RADIO TELEPHONE FREQUENCIES TO ALL STATIONS. THE PORT AUTHORITY AT MULDWARKA PORT WAS INFORMED ON VHF TELEPHONE ABOUT GROUNDING OF VESSEL.

Location: Sandhakud Sea beach off Paradip Port, India
SummaryOfEvents: The fishing trawler JAL PARI-1 wanted to dock at Paradip Port on 28th June 2007 for her annual inspection/dry docking repairs, but was not allowed to because of the ISPS code restriction. The crew of the trawler lifted anchor to move on, but could not start the engine in time. As a result, the trawer drifted on a high swell at strong wind speed, towards the local beach off Paradip port. It stranded on the beach at around 05.00 hours on 29th June 2007. Her crew was made up of Thai and Mynamar nationals, at least eight of whom lost their lives. The exact number could not be confirmed because another vessel, the Jal-Pari-3, had also washed up on the same beach at the same time.

SOLASStatus: STAR PROVIDENCE: SOLAS, THOR MERCHANT: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
AT 04.05 LT ON 29TH JUNE 2007 THE M/V STAR PROVIDENCE WAS EN ROUTE FROM KAOSSHIUNG TO BATA, WHEN IT  COLLIDED WITH M/V THOR MERCHANT IN POSTION 01º44N 104º39 E, 28NM NORTH OF HORSBURG LIGHTHOUSE.
THE VESSEL WAS LOADED WITH BAGGED RICE 39.199.96 MT.
THERE WERE NO CASUALTIES AND NO POLLUTION FROM EITHER OF THE VESSELS.

When a ro-ro passenger ship entered the port of call, its usual quay berth was not available, as another ship could not depart because of bad weather. Consequently, the passenger ship had to berth at another quay. Because of heavy wind and lack of thrusters, the passenger ship was not able to turn around and it had to berth on port side instead of starboard side as planned. 

When the ship was loaded and had departed from the berth, a rescue vessel was standby to help to turn the ship around. The passenger ship went astern the stern facing the wind. After a short distance, the ship stopped and swung around to port. At this point, the wind was on port side, approximately 15 m/s. The wind was strong on port side and the ship drifted to starboard. The ship was getting closer and closer to the end of the pier, which the ship subsequently hit. 

While this was happening, attempts were made to navigate the ship further starboard. After the collision with the pier, the ship was navigated to the outer habour where the rescue vessel examined the damage. It was established that there were indentures and a hole. Shortly after, water level indicator on deck 1 triggered an alarm for deck 1. It was decided to return to the quay.

QUEST is a passenger ship, which sails tourists on one week round trips in Greenland waters. The actual voyage started in Kangerlussuaq on 22 June 2007 with 54 passengers and a crew of 20.
On the morning of 27th June the ship was en route from Equip Sermia to Qeqertarsuaq (Godhavn), when it grounded in calm weather 0.24 miles from the coast of the Disko Isle, approximately 1 mile east of Qeqertarsuaq.
At low water the ship listed about 15 degrees to starboard and the passengers were transferred to the shore by the ship’s Zodiac craft.
The ship was pulled free on 29th June 2007, and after an inspection by divers was allowed to proceed to Nuuk Shipyard for temporary repair of cracks in the bulb and of several dents and deformed frames in the bottom.
The ship was pulled free on 29 June and was after an inspection by divers allowed proceeding to Nuuk Shipyard for temporary repair of cracks in the bulb and of several dents and deformed frames in the bottom.

On May 26, 2007 m/t BARRI was moored at JM-15 jetty in Riga harbour. Ship was being prepared  for a trip to RKB 7 jetty (same harbour) to collect bilge water from m/v KHATANGA. Chief engineer repeatedly tried to start the main engine for two hrs. These attempts were unsuccessful. At about 1622(UTC+3) there was an explosion in ships engine room which also caused fire. As a result of explosion both crew members lost their lives and ship was totally demolished.
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Pollution,Loss of life
Cargo1: sludge, bilge waters, oil products with flash point >+60 C

SOLASStatus: GREEN PIONEER: SOLAS, HONG QI 201: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: At 09.44 hours LT on 26th June 2007 a collision occurred in lat 31 23.9N, long 121 33.6E between combined chemical and oil tank GREEN PIONEER (2562 gt, built 2000) and bulker Hong Qi 201 (12096 gt, built 1980). Green Pioneer sustained damage to her starboard bow and Hong Qi 201 was damaged in the middle of the port side. -- DPS Teamhead Surveyors.

Le mardi 26 Juin 2007, peu avant 04:00 heures le navire ravitailleur de plate-forme française « Athena » affrété par Total E & P Congo à la compagnie Bourbon Offshore Surf,  subit un envahissement d’eau de mer du compartiment machine par tribord, alors qu’il est en « position dynamique » à 1 mille nautique au nord de la plate-forme Taf-E, au Sud-Ouest de  Pointe Noire, Congo.
La situation est rapidement évaluée et jugée suffisamment critique par le capitaine qui déclenche l’alarme de poste d’abandon. Soixante-trois personnes se trouvent à bord : vingt-six hommes d’équipage et trente-sept techniciens embarqués.

Simultanément, les tentatives  d’assèchement du compartiment machine et d’isolement de la traverse eau de mer tribord, effectuée par les second et 3ème  officiers mécaniciens, seront mises en échec par le niveau d’eau déjà atteint dans le compartiment machine.

Un plan de remorquage est décidé avec  la cellule  de crise de la compagnie, au moyen de deux autres navires présents sur le site, et « l’Athéna » sera échoué à 7.4 milles nautiques  au Nord-ouest de Pointe Noire. Après une tentative de renflouement, « l’Athena » est déclarée en perte totale. L’origine de la voie d’eau a été identique fin mars 2008.

On 19th June 2007 the general cargo ship SEA GLORY was in ballast condition en route from Dubai to the the Indian port of Gujarat. At approximately 36 - 48 hours away from her destination, she encountered heavy seas and started to roll and pitch. To avoid the effects of adverse weather the Master took the swell on the vessel's Quarters. The SEA GLORY dropped anchor off Jakau port on 25th June 2007 at 09.00 hours LT. At 13.14 hours LT her anchor dragged and a second anchor was dropped at 13.30 hours, but she continued to drift towards the Indian coast. By this time, she had dragged her anchor for almost five nautical miles. At 20.17 hours LT both anchors dragged again. The starboard chain subsequently parted and, at 20.57 hours LT the vessel grounded. On 29th June 2007 ingress of seawater was observed in No. 2 (P&S) ballast tanks. On 30th June 2007 the rate of ingress had increased, and it was apparent that the vessel could not be saved. On 1st July 2007 the vessel listed to 20 degrees, and on 3rd July 2007 she listed to 35 degrees. The vesssel was abandoned at 11.30 hours LT and by 14.30 hours LT all crew had been rescued by the Indian Coast Guard.

Location: about 2 miles from Khanderi Island, off Mumbai Harbour
SummaryOfEvents: On 23rd June 2007 , the tug boat KRISHNA I and Dumb Barge Radha IV as a composite unit fitted with Articulate coupling system left Mumbai port en route to Revdanda port on the west coast of India. They encountered inclement weather that resulted in the failure of the Articulate Coupling system, and tug and barge became detatched.  Dumb Barge Radha IV hit the area of Krishna I's engine room resulting in ingress of water, and Krishna I eventually sank close to the vicinity of Khanderi Port Island at about midday on 25th June 2007. Dumb barge Radha IV drifted into harbour and grounded close to the shore of the naval establishment on North Karanja island near Mora. The tug had about 10  kilo litres of diesel oil on board, but no oil spillage was seen. SAR operations were carried out by port crafts and indian coast guard surface craft. Air sorties were not possible due to rough sea conditions. One crew member (the cook) died as a result of the incident and his body was found on the rocks. The other 24 crew members survived.

Location: 42 nautical miles southwest of cape Egmont
SummaryOfEvents:
At about 13:30 hours on 21 June 2007, the specialised bulk iron sand carrier Taharoa Express left its single buoy mooring in Port Taharoa to seek refuge in Tasman Bay from forecast severe weather.
The ship had been scheduled to have a slurry of about 116 000 dry tonnes of iron sand mixed with water pumped aboard. Earlier during the loading process the ship's duct keel had flooded with water from the slurry-loading process, disabling the ship's ballast and cargo de-watering systems. The water had gravitated from the cargo overflow recesses into the duct keel through welding access holes left unsealed after steel renewal in dry dock prior to the loading voyage. When the Taharoa Express departed Port Taharoa it had an estimated 17 800 cubic metres (m3)of water on top of the iron sand that had settled in 5 of its cargo holds, as well as number 6 water ballast hold and several ballast tanks being partially full.
The ship initially had a 1.5 degree (°) starboard list when it sailed.
During the voyage to Tasman Bay, the starboard list progressively increased, unnoticed by key personnel on board until about 01:50 hours on 22 June when the ship took a larger roll that woke key personnel, who found that the ship had a 17° starboard list. The Taharoa Express was manoeuvred for the remainder of the trip to Tasman Bay to minimise the motion of the ship in the heavy seas, but the list reached 22° before the ship reached the shelter of Tasman Bay.

The cause of the list was the progressive shift of iron sand in all loaded holds owing to wash action caused by sloshing free water, and possibly contributed to by an en masse shift of iron sand in one or more cargo holds.

SummaryOfEvents: At 08.00 hours on 11th June 2007 the m/v WINPO sailed from the port of Dhuvasuru (Maldives) en route to Mumbai, with an Indian crew towing an empty barge registered in Mongolia. The vessel encountered rough weather on 16th June 2007 and the towing rope parted four times between 15th - 19th June, but was successfully reconnected by the crew. On 21st June 2006 the towing rope parted again, and became entangled in the propeller, causing the main engine to stop functioning. Both tug and barge began drifting and the starboard bow of the barge hit the port quarter of the tug, creating a deep hole. The accommodation area of the tug began to flood and the vessel sank approximately 10 nautical miles west off Cannanore on the Kerala coast. The crew abandoned the vessel and then managed to get into the life raft. apart from one who got onto the drifting barge, and another who was washed away. Three crew members lost their lives, and three were injured.

The container ship MSC PEGGY departed port of Houston on June 20th 2007 at about 20.28 hours Lt with cargo on board (998 cont with approx weight of 20408 T ), bound for Altamira Mexico. Dep. Draft noted as F 9.80 M A 10.8 M. Pilot on board.
Weather conditions were good, including visibility. WIND/SEAS N-NE'ly 10 KTS/2.
Traffic in ship channel was light.
At approx. 21.15 hours LT a push boat and barge were noticed over the ship's port bow about 1,3 miles away, navigating in opposite course to the MSC PEGGY. Pilot estabilished contact via VHF with skipper of push boat and requested passing "PORT TO PORT". Moments later master and pilot noticed the push boat and barge turning to their port and then stopping, thus blocking the navigational channel. The Pilot confirmed with push boat skipper that push boat lost steering at this time, as MSC PEGGY was making 10 KTS trough the water. At 21.20 hours LT the Master ordered the course be changed to port, with the intention of steering away from imminent collission with push BOAT/BARGE. Engine was given "ASTERN".
At 21.22 hours LT the vessel ran aground to the east side of the navigational channel, although
no grounding impact was felt. Soon afterwards, by using ship's engine and bow truster, the
vessel was able to re-float free and continue her passage. Pilot advised United States Coast Guard, who in turn instructed vessel to proceed to FW Anchorage. Divers' survey revealed no damage to the under water parts of the vessel, nor its attachments. USCG rescinded restriction and allowed vessel to proceed on her intended voyage.

RORO / Cargo vessel was on passage when  fire alarm and main engine failure occured simultaneously.  Thick smoke was discovered in the engine room and access doors and fire flaps were secured.  Crew were mustered on the Bridge and two teams of firefighters were formed.  One team entered the engine room throught the normal access and the second came from forward through a pipe tunnel access.  Firefighters wearing breathing apparatus were able to put out the fire using portable dry powder extinguishers.  Fixed systems were available, but were not used.  Subsequent investigation determined that a low pressure fuel inlet pipe situated between the two banks of the main  "V "engine had broken allowing fuel oil, pre-heated at 110 to 120oC to spill onto hot engine components.  Fractured low pressure fuel pipe was made from steel and approximately 30mm in diameter.  Pipe was supported locally by brackets but a section about 100mm long had detached and was missing.  Fire was extinguished rapidly, but area in a 6m radius was heavily damaged, particularly engine controls, governer, cabling and deckhead fittings.  Company reported that they were very pleased with crew response to the emergency.

On 23 May 2007, the Panamanian registered bulk carrier Pasha Bulker anchored 2.4 miles off the coast near Newcastle, New South Wales. The ship had sufficient water ballast on board for the good weather at the time, and was not expected to load its coal cargo for about three weeks.
At midday on 7 June, Pasha Bulker’s master veered more anchor cable after a gale warning was issued. The weather deteriorated and shortly after midnight, the wind had reached gale force.
At 05.00 hours LT on 8 June, the wind had increased to strong gale force and the weather was severe. At 06.25 hous LT Pasha Bulker started to drag its anchor. The master decided to put to sea and at 07.48 hours LT the anchor was aweigh. The ship was then 1.2 miles from the shore and, with, the southeast wind fine on the starboard bow, it made good a north-easterly course. At 09.06 hours LT , the master altered the ship’s course to starboard to put the wind on the port bow in an attempt to make good a southerly course on a south-southeasterly heading. However, its heading became south-westerly and, with the wind on the port beam, the ship started to rapidly approach the coast.
At 09.31 hours LT, with Nobbys Beach 0.8 of a mile away, the master attempted a starboard turn. The manoeuvre did not succeed and at 09.46 hours LT, with grounding imminent, he requested assistance from authorities ashore. At 09.51 hours LT, Pasha Bulker grounded on Nobbys Beach and the ship’s momentum carried it further onto the beach. The crew were evacuated by helicopter during the afternoon.
On 2 July, Pasha Bulker was successfully refloated. The ship was temporarily repaired in Newcastle and on 26 July, taken in tow to Vietnam to undergo permanent repairs.

A dry cargo vessel was on passage from Lisbon to Felixstowe when she suffered a main engine failure.

The onboard team were unable to repair the engine and it was eventually towed back into Lisbon.  Investigations found that there had been a catastrophic fatigue failure of the upper end of one of the connecting rods.  The damaged rod flayed around in the sump and damaged the cylinder block.  The damaged and undamaged connecting rods were subjected to laboratory examination where the cause of failure was attrributed to fatigue.

In the meantime the management company instructed that no work was to be carried out in the vicinity of the engine.

Le samedi 19 mai 2007 à 12h45, le navire à passagers ENEZ SUN III appareille du port de Sainte Evette, à Audierne, pour se rendre à l’île de Sein avec cent-trente-six passagers à son
bord.
A 13h41, le navire embouque le Chenal Oriental d’accès à l’île. Il se trouve par le
travers des roches Boukinou, position 48° 02,627 N – 004°49,510 W, lorsque surgit une vague
déferlante qui le frappe par tribord et le couche sur bâbord. Les quatre-vingt passagers se
trouvant sur le pont supérieur sont projetés contre le bastingage bâbord, deux d’entre eux
tombent à la mer, dix sept autres sont blessés dont quatre plus grièvement.
Le navire se redresse, l’équipage intervient immédiatement et lance des bouées
couronnes aux deux passagers tombés à la mer qui s’en saisissent. Le CROSS Corsen est
informé de la situation et met en oeuvre le canot SNSM VILLE DE PARIS de l’île de Sein. Le
ligneur PATIENCE, qui se trouve à proximité, est mobilisé. L’ENEZ SUN III ne peut récupérer les personnes tombées à l’eau, en raison de son franc bord et de la forte houle qui fait rouler le
navire.
En moins de vingt minutes, les deux passagers tombés à la mer sont récupérés, l’un
par le ligneur PATIENCE, qui le transfère sur le canot SNSM, l’autre par le canot SNSM. Les deux victimes sont évacuées, l’une vers le CHU de Brest par l’hélicoptère du SAMU TONNERRE 29, l’autre par l’hélicoptère de la Sécurité Civile DRAGON 29 vers l’hôpital de Quimper.
Les passagers sont comptés par l’équipage. Les blessés sont pris en charge par deux
médecins se trouvant à bord parmi les passagers. Aucun blessé ne nécessitant une évacuation
immédiate, l’ENEZ SUN III fait alors route retour vers le port de Sainte Evette, à Audierne, où il
arrive à 14h45. Les blessés sont évacués par ambulance.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

Location: Off west coast of Myanmar (en route to Yangon from Chittagong)
SummaryOfEvents: On 17th May 2007 the general cargo ship DOLPHIN II (flag State Panama) sank in bad weather off the west coast of Myanmar, en route to Yangon (Myanmar) from Chittagong (Bangladesh). Unconfirmed news reports stated that eleven crew members were rescued, but nine went missing.

At the time of the accident, the mv FOREST-1, sailing under the flag of St. Kitts & Nevis, was berthed in Emden harbour.  The voyage from Papenburg to Istanbul had been interrupted at Emden as a result of technical defects.
During a Port State Control the representative of the See-BG had, amongst other deficiencies, ascertained deficiencies in the performance of the lifeboat drill and had issued a detention order.
The FOREST-1's single lifeboat was a combined life and rescue boat.
The crew carried out drills to improve their skills.  On 16 May 2007, after an initial drill, the ship's command ordered a second drill to be carried out.  All stations were manned by the same persons as in the first attempt.  While lowering the boat there was an incident that produced an increased load on the releasing hooks.  Thereupon the aft releasing hook opened.  The boat swung downwards, still held by the forward releasing hook.  As a result of the excessive load, the forward releasing hook thereupon tore out of the hull of the lifeboat which fell into the water from a height of 7m.  Ingress of water caused a quick sinking of the stern.  
Three of the six seamen in the boat were able to exit it.  Two men died, one was seriously injured.  The casualties were recovered by rescue personnel.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Serious injuries,Ship remains fit to proceed

SummaryOfEvents:
At about 0230 on 16 May 2007, the bulk carrier Ormiston sailed from Melbourne, Victoria, bound for Thevenard, South Australia. At about 0512, the ship rounded the Hovell Pile beacon and entered the South Channel in Port Phillip. At about 0521, Ormiston entered ‘The Cut’, the narrowest part of the channel, from the east making good about 15 knots.
At about 0230, the second mate on board the roll-on/roll-off general cargo ship Searoad Mersey contacted Point Lonsdale vessel traffic service (VTS) to provide an estimated time of arrival at the entrance to Port Phillip and was advised of the traffic movements within the port. At about 0420, Searoad Mersey’s master, who also held a pilotage exemption for Port Phillip and had conducted over 1300 transits of the port, contacted VTS and received updated traffic information, including Ormiston’s estimated movements.
At about 0435, Searoad Mersey passed Point Lonsdale lighthouse and entered Port Phillip. At about 0521, when the ship entered ‘The Cut’ from the west making good about 15 knots, the master had forgotten that Ormiston was approaching and did not see the approaching ship until immediately before the two ships passed. At about 0523, Searoad Mersey and Ormiston passed within 20 metres of each other in ‘The Cut’ at a combined speed of about 30 knots.
The ATSB investigation found that Searoad Mersey’s bridge team members had not effectively implemented bridge resource management principles, were not keeping an adequate lookout and had lost situational awareness. The investigation also found that the ships did not communicate with each other until after the incident and that the Point Lonsdale VTS was not aware of the incident until after it had occurred.
The ATSB has issued four recommendations and one safety advisory notice to address the safety issues identified in the report.

During this manoeuvre, the vessel was passed by a bunker barge intending to proceed alongside a vessel berthed directly ahead. Soon after the cargo ship manoeuvred ahead she was impeded by the bunker barge. To avoid collision with the barge, the cargo ship went astern towards her original berth but was set onto the berthed vessel and the quay by the strong wind.  Damage to the cargo vessel included cracking to her foecastle deck and some buckled plating on her port quarter. Damage caused to the vessel alongside was superficial.

At around 19:20 hours on 5 May 2007 the general cargo ship Emuna, sailing under Dutch flag, was en route from New Holland/Great Britain to Rostock. Before starting on the planned passage thought the Kiel Canal, the Emuna tied up for a stopover at the South Quay in Brunsbuttel.

On the North western Roadstead (NW-Reede) before Brunsbuttel the German canal pilot came on board via the pilot’s transfer platform. Once at the South Quay in Brunsbuttel, a pilot ladder was deployed for the pilot to disembark. This pilot ladder had been damaged the previous day during an incident in Great Britain, when a pilot boat briefly got entangled with the ladder.
The bottom steps, which had been partially detached in the incident, had been removed on board the Emuna, whereupon the ladder was considered fit for further use.

When on the day of the accident the pilot, who had not been informed of the damage, stepped onto the pilot ladder, the ropes tore on both sides. The pilot fell a distance of several meters and landed on a wooden fender fitted in front of the quay wall. In doing so he suffered not insignificant injuries, as a result of which he was unable to work for three weeks.

Nobody else was injured. No environmental harmful substances were released.

Location: North-West of the Azores, North Atlantic Ocean
SummaryOfEvents:
On 27 April 2007, the German tanker SEACOD was on passage from Immingham (United Kingdom) to Savannah (United States) when north-west of the Azores a philippine able-bodied seaman was fatally injured whilst carrying out maintenance work on a mooring line on the main deck forecastle.
In doing so, an eye splice on a synthetic wire rope of Atlas type was to be rigged on deck.  In the process a ladder rung to which a strop was attached broke. This deflected the Atlas rope by 90 degrees.  The rebounding rope hit the able-bodied seaman and hurtled him on deck or, rather, onto a deck stringer.  Despite rescue measures being promptly started and an emergency physician being flown in by helicopter, the life of the casualty could not be saved.

SummaryOfEvents: On April 26th 2007 the San remo was en route from Poland to lake Vänern, Sweden. When the vessel entered the Gothenburg archipelago the master arrived at the bridge. He had worked almost 21 hours out of the previous 24. The vessel failed to turn starboard at a way point, and grounded at 03.21 hours LT. During the night the San Remo was refloated and proceeded to port on its own power to discharge its cargo. The vessel then went to the shipyard for repair.

The MEDINA CARRIER departed Davao at 17.55 hours LT on the 24th April 2007 loaded with a cargo of fruit with destination Yokohama. Drafts on departure were For’d 5-71 metres, Aft 6-50 metres. Intended route was to round Cape San Augustin and take a northerly course off the East Coast of Mindanao, before setting a course directly for Yokohama Bay.

At 20.53 hours the vessel received a message from Charterers to proceed to Yokohama at ‘Maximum Safe Speed. Weather Permitting’
At 05.40 hours the Master reported that the vessel had ‘touched bottom’ at uncharted position Lat 07-38.7 N Long 126-35.2 E. The message intimated that the integrity of fuel tanks, ballast tanks, and bilges, had not been breached, but that there was a problem starting the main engine due to low lube oil pressure.

Subsequent reports from the vessel revealed that once the vessel had floated free, there had been damage to the double bottom ballast tanks, and that there was sea water leaking through the main engine crank case doors, which indicated that the main engine sump had been breached, and the main engine was therefore totally inoperable.

After floating free of the bottom obstruction, the vessel drifted southwards at a rate of approximately 2 knots until able to anchor in position  Lat 07-17.3 N  Long 126-36.5 E. Vessel remained in this position until under tow by ‘DAVTUG X11’ at 18.12 hours on the 26th April 2007.

SOLASStatus: PETER CROMBIE: Unknown/unspecified, SILKY OCEAN: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents:
On the morning of 23 April 2007, the Australian fishing vessel Peter Crombie was at anchor about 30 miles south of Robe, South Australia, and the vessel’s three crew members were below deck sleeping. 

The weather was fine with good visibility. There was a swell of about one metre from the 
east-southeast and seas of about 1.5 m. The wind was from the east-southeast at 12 to 18 knots.

At about 11.50 hours LT, the Panamanian registered bulk carrier SILKY OCEAN collided with Peter Crombie. SILKY OCEAN'S bridge watchkeeper had not detected Peter Crombie, either visually or by radar.

After the collision, Peter Crombie’s skipper tried to contact the ship using his vessel’s very high frequency radio. However, SILKY CROMBIE’s bridge watchkeeper did not acknowledge the call and made no attempt to communicate with the fishing vessel. 

While SILKY OCEAN sustained no damage as a result of the collision, Peter Crombie’s hull had been severely damaged and the vessel was taking on water. Fortunately, the fishing vessel’s bilge pumps were able to keep up with the ingress of water.

Peter Crombie’s skipper notified the vessel’s owners of the collision and then set a course for Robe. By 1700, the vessel was all fast alongside the wharf in Robe.

The fishing vessel HERCULES was a factory trawler of 7805 GT, designed with plants for deep freezing fish. The vessel was built in Spain for Russian flag in 1990 and was purchased from Vanuatu by a Faroese company in February 2007 and registered in the Faroese Register of Shipping together with her sister ship POSEIDON. 

The vessels were fishing with pelagic trawls after horse mackerel in the South Pacific Ocean. The catch was frozen without being processed and stowed into the freezing hold.

There were 116 crew members, technicians and ship’s officers on board, spread over 6 nationalities.

On Friday 20 April, the chief engineer of POSEIDON discovered that two newly in-stalled fixtures for fluorescent tubes had become overheated and begun melting the plastic sockets for the tubes and subsequently the plastic covers of the fixtures. The same type of fixtures had also been installed in HERCULES.
 
The chief engineer switched off the electric power supply for these fixtures and warned his colleague in HERCULES by an E-mail the warning.

On the same evening, a fire broke out on board HERCULES in the hold on 1st deck, where great amounts of plastic and corrugated cardboard packing were stored.

Very dense smoke spread extremely fast all over the vessel and also to the bridge, because a large number of doors and hatches were open, and because a cable shaft was leading not divided into sections from the cargo hold on 2nd deck up to a low space below the bridge.

The fire alarm systems functioned for a very short while and had only a poor effect.

A distress signal was transmitted via VHF to other fishing vessels in the vicinity. Four vessels arrived to give assistance within approximately one hour.

The crew gathered on the forecastle while smoke divers were searching in the accom-modation to get all crew members out.

Due to lack of air supply in their air breathing apparatuses it was necessary to dismiss the smoke divers quickly.

No fire fighting was carried out inside the vessel due to lack of air supply in the air breathing apparatuses.

11 crew members perished due to smoke inhalation.

105 persons were evacuated from the ship to other fishing vessels by the use of the vessel’s life rafts.

The vessel was on fire for approximately three weeks. All processing compartments, cargo spaces, accommodation and other machinery spaces burned out. The engine room remained almost undamaged by the fire. Approximately one month after the fire broke out, the vessel was towed to a Chilean port. It was eventually declared a ‘Total Constructive Loss’.
Consequences1: Serious injuries,Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Total loss of the ship

SummaryOfEvents:

During rigmove of Transocean Rather W of the Shetlands Bourbon Dolphin (BD) capsized to port while deploying anchor chain no 2 in a Northerly direction. The vessel had prior to the capsizing experienced severe difficulties maintaining the intended course. It had deviated in an E direction towards deployed anchor chain no 3, and was at the time of capsizing about 900 m E of intended track/position. Immediately prior to capsizing inner starboard tow pin was lowered and the chain applied its force towards the outer port tow pin. Subsequently the vessel experienced a list of about 20-40° to port for about 15 s before righting itself. Then the vessel listed to port again and capsized. The winch emergency release was active during the final list/capsize.

The wind was at near gale and the surface current has been estimated in excess of 2.5 m/s in E direction. The rig and BD had about 1800 m of anchor chain between them. 

Offshore Tug/Supply Ship Highland Valour (IMO no 9249506) had about 1 hr prior to the capsizing grappled the anchor chain behind BD in an attempt to assist the BD back on intended track. This attempt was, however, unsuccessful and culminated 40 min prior to the capsizing in a near collision between Highland Valour (HV) and BD. During evasive manouvering HV lost its grip on the chain and did not attempt to grapple again.  There is currently no indication that this incident contributed to the capsize of BD some 40 minutes later.

The BD had 14 crewmembers and one passenger (14 y.o.). 7 of the crewmembers and the 14 year old boy were lost. 

BD remained afloat after the capsize. During the rescue operations attempt was made by divers from the UK Coast Guard to enter the hull to search for possible survivors. This was aborted due to safety concerns for the divers. The vessel was examined by Rescue Operator Vehicle (ROV).

At 2116 on 15. of April the vessel sank at about 1100 m depth. The anchor chain had been cut in preparation of the salvage operation and to remove the vessel away from the rig.
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life

On 7th April 2007 the dredger "Tauracavor" left New York (U.S.A.) for Colon (Panama) towed by the tug "American Challenger".
At 10:00 hours EDT on 11th April 2007, whilst en route at approximately 5 kts on a handing of 227 D T with 25-30 kt SSE winds and an Easterly 3 feet swell, the weather began to increase, despite the contrary and mutiple weather forecasts the tug master had obtained earlier that day.
The flotilla hove-to at 11:45 hours with SE winds of 45-50 kts.  At 14:00 hours, the seas increased in size to 10-12 feet, but the flotilla remained stable.
At 14.50 hours, the tug master was notified by his officer on watch that the dredger had begun to list.  The tug master immediately contacted the USCG and his home office, who in turn contacted the dredger owner and alerted a salvage company to begin immediate mobilization.
The dredger appeared to be stable but then rolled to port with a list of approx.  20-25 degrees.  The dredger capsized at 15:35 hours, about  27 miles south of Wilmington- North Carolina (U.S.A.) in approximately 105 feet of water.  There was no indication of any pollution.  Drug test were administered to the master and alternate captain by urine analysis; all tests were negative.
At first the bow section of the dredger remained floating (due to air bubbles), but on 18th April 2007 at approximately 17:00 hours the bow section disappeared beneath the surface and sank towards the sea bed.

At about 15.00 hours on 12th March 2007, the unmanned barge SEATOW 61 was anchored by the crew of its tug about three miles off Carnarvon, Western Australia, following advice from the Carnarvon harbour master. When anchored, the crew set the barge’s anchor lights to operate automatically using a timer.
At about 06.10 hours LT on 18 March, in near total darkness, the recreational vessel, Norma Jean, with four persons on board, left the Carnarvon boat harbour. At about 06.25 Norma Jean collided with Seatow 61 and sank almost immediately. All four occupants of the boat died as a result of the collision.
The ATSB investigation found that Norma Jean’s skipper may not have seen the barge until seconds before the impact and may have mistaken the barge’s anchor lights for the lights of two separate vessels. Norma Jean’s speed was inappropriate for the dark conditions and the use of the boat’s interior lights probably reduced the skipper’s night vision. 
The investigation also found that the Carnarvon harbour master, who is based in Perth, about 900 km south of Carnarvon, was not fully aware of recreational vessel activities in Carnarvon when providing advice on where to anchor the barge.
The report issued four recommendations and four safety advisory notices with the aim of preventing further incidents of this type.

A Ro-RO passenger ferry was on passage to the UK when, at 0224, a fire alarm sounded indicating a fire in between the main engine exhaust and the outer funnel skin.  The fire alarm was investigated and a fire was confirmed.  Attempts were made to extinguish it with a first aid extinguisher but because of the extremely limited access this was unsuccessful.

The fire party were mustered and quickly brought the fire under control and extinguished it by 0308.  The crew carried out a boundary search but there were no hot spots.  The vessel continued under power throughout the incident.  On arrival the vessel was met by the Fire and Rescue Service who also carried out a boundary search and confirmed that the fire had been extinguished.

On investigation it was found that a large number of leaves and other carbonaceous debris had accumulated between the exhaust pipes causing the fire having been blown through the open sections of the funnel casing.  The company has now established a process for regularly checking the area is free of debris.

There were no injuries.

A newly completed military Ro-Ro vessel was on passage to a south coast port when, at 1314, the port and starboard propulsion transformer room heat detectors were found to be approaching their set levels of 59 deg C.  This was normal for extended running at 195 shaft rpm.

The master and chief engineer were informed and regular 30 minutes monitoring rounds were established as had become normal practice.  At 1650 the room temperature was recorded at 62 deg C.  At 1711 the ship experienced a blackout and at the same time the ship lost its 6.6.kV main propulsion power supply and at 1714 the smoke detector in the transformer room lobby activated.  The fire party assembled, HV supplies were isolated and the HV transformer room door opened to allow the fire team to attack the fire.  The fire was confirmed extinguished at 1732.  The integrated Platform Management System was re-instated .  As a result of the fire and water damage to the port pre-magnatizing transformer the port propulsion system could not be used.

The vessel made its way under its own power to port.  On investigation the evidence pointed to a flash over between the pre-magnatizing transformers due to thermal stress which set fire to the perspex terminal cover. The high temperatures in the transformer room were known as a class problem and are believed to have set of the sequence of events.

The subject of excessive transformer room temperatures are the subject of a separate study by the vessel's manufacturer's.

“CONTEXTO Y CIRCUNSTANCIAS EN QUE OCURRIÓ EL SINIESTRO”                                                 

1.- El día 27 de Febrero del 2007,  fondea en el Puerto de  San Antonio, el Bulk Carrier “Port Victoria”, de bandera Islas Marshall número IMO 9262637, procedente del puerto de San Lorenzo Argentina, con sus cinco bodegas, conteniendo graneles para descargar en el terminal Puerto Panul.

2.- Previo al inicio de la descarga, se hace necesaria la acreditación ante la Autoridad Marítima de la condición de “Gas Free”, debido a que el fumigante empleado (Fosfina), inflamable y perjudicial para el hombre dependiendo de su concentración y tiempo de exposición,  podria causar incluso la muerte. Por lo anterior, se procura la ausencia  de gases de fumigantes en las bodegas de manera que exista un ambiente en condición segura para su ingreso. Esta condición se logra mediante una ventilación natural y forzada, transcurrido 5 días de su embarque, durante la navegación al puerto de descarga.

El proceso de fumigación mencionado se inicia insertando en la parte superior de la carga, a través de lancetas a una profundidad promedio de 50 cm,  tabletas de fosfuro de aluminio, las cuales al cabo de una o dos horas, comienzan a descomponerse liberando el gas llamado fosfina, el que por ser más pesado que el aire, va descendiendo por los intersticios entre los granos, demandando aproximadamente cuatro a cinco días en llegar al fondo de  bodega. 

El compuesto remanente, una vez generado el gas, es un hidróxido de aluminio el cual contiene hasta un 2% de fosfina, lo que es  inocuo para el ser humano, animales y aves. La principal característica adversa de este residuo (hidróxido de aluminio) es el hecho que el fosfuro remanente reacciona exotérmicamente al entrar en contacto con el agua.

3.- El producto pellet de girasol, es un granel de origen vegetal, no tiene condiciones explosivas, pero ante un aumento de humedad produce  una acidificación de las grasas y quema de proteínas, generando una fuente de calor que condensa humedad y aumenta la temperatura llegando a un punto que puede generar un proceso de autocombustión y la creación de un ciclo continuo que se auto-alimenta.

4.-  La nave recala a puerto con un foco de incendio controlado en la bodega N°5.
